issue_title: Update all TF Tree elements for new robot
issue_contents: The new robot has different locations for the wheels, cameras, sensors, etc. These are recorded in the tf tree, and a new file must be made with these values for the new robot.
This is a cross-team task, so consult with Mechanical for the highest accuracy location and orientation of each item, and record it in the updated tf tree.
The new base_frame is in the center of the center drive wheel axle, with the +x axis going forwards, the +y axis going left, and the +z axis going up.
This is addressed by the new URDF file in the igvc_description package
TF trees have been updated but should be tested when robot is complete

issue_title: CPU usage testing
issue_contents: It would be worth to test how much cpu the watcher thread or gateway system consumes.
Previously, I have seen rosbridge or mjpeg_server takes more than 60% of cpu power which would not be desirable since we would like to run gateway system permanently in background.
Quick tests - almost negligible. And users can slow down the watcher thread by parameter if they wish to as well.

issue_title: /dev/tty/ACM0 disappears when OpenCR's 12V output is used
issue_contents: I'm trying to connect a custom circuit board to the OpenCR card, using the 12V output show at the left of the following image as a source (this custom board doesn't take up more than some miliamps of current).
Nevertheless, at the moment that I connect to this output, the USB connection from the OpenCR board to the Raspberry Pi is lost. Using
I was able to see that it indeed happens at the very moment I plug it in.
Plugging and unplugging the USB cable does nothing, the device can only be seen after turning the OpenCR board off and on again.
What could be the issue? Thanks in advance for any tips that might help me to identify the problem.

output  (J10 on the OpenCR schematics) instead of the 12V regulated output, I don't have the problem anymore. I would still like to know what is the problem though with the 12V output though, as I suspect one of the two might be happening:

The problem came back after trying to use my card, even using the Power Out output. I tried powering the card with an external source and I still had the same problem, which means that it's not a matter of current drain.
First of all, check your power supply is providing enough power. I sometimes get a bad adapter that does not provide enough current written on it.
If you are already supplying power with decent power supply or battery, please check whether the 3 analog input signals from your card do not exceed 5V.
Although 12V and 5V port are shared power from a 12V regulator, they should be able to supply enough power to RPI3 and your custom card that only consumes several miliamps.
The power supply is indeed ok (but since it didn't seem to be the problem, I'm trying to do my tests using the power from the "Power Out" output).
The analog input signals don't exceed 5V. If they did, though, how could that be a problem for the USB port?
Thanks a lot for your attention!
Well, I thought if the analog input signal exceeds 5V, then it might reset or enable hardware protection from MCU to lead such issue.
Have you tried reading your custom card on other boards?
I see, can you point me some document regarding the MCU in which I can try to study its behavior?

I have used the same custom card with an Arduino Uno board and I didn't have this problem. Moreover, I have managed to use it with the Turtlebot3: sometimes it works for hours with no problem and then it just randomly stops, sometimes it just doesn't work since the beginning.
It was only my theory that unexpected input might cause reset and it is not written in the manual.
If you setup the Arduino shield input ports on OpenCR correctly and having this isuse, I'd recommend you to get a repair service.
There are several reasons of not working properly, but it is difficult to figure out the cause without looking into each case.
If you are experiencing some issue, please let us know with more information such as logs, captured screens or videos.
Those will greatly help us to figure out what went wrong.
This issue will be closed since there were no actions for a while. You can reopen this issue to show this issue to the users whenever. Thanks.

issue_title: [proposal] trajectory_interface
issue_contents: It's looking like another module of the ros_control toolchain that we could provide a pluggin-able interface for is trajectory interpolation.
The goal here would be to provide a simple interface that includes:

There should be an emphasis on dealing not just with long discrete trajectories, but also for use as an interpolator for streaming contexts like teleoperation. To that end, depending on performance, it might make sense to also provide an interface for
This is based on discussion on joint trajectory controllers and the idea to split some of the features of the current PR2 joint trajectory controllerthe robot control SIG here:

Sounds like a good plan!  Not sure where you say 'pluggin-able' interface, if you mean a plugin that can be loaded at runtime, or just a set of re-usable components in a library that can be integrated at compile time by a controller builder.  For this use case I'm imagining that the latter makes most sense.
I did mean a library that can be loaded at runtime. We can still build a library of loadable tractory generators / interpolators, but I like being able to load such components as plugins.

Might be worthwhile looking at all the options we have before diving deeper and re-inventing the wheel. For the interpolation itself, the options include (1) KDL (2) Reflexxes (3) MoveIt! itself does interpolation inside robot_state and also (for trajectory generation) has the iterative spline smoother (4) Some of the old code in arm_navigation could be reused (5) I think Bullet has some interpolation code that might also be available through TF. I would prefer not coming up with a whole new solution but wrapping the existing ones through a really lightweight interface.
I would prefer not coming up with a whole new solution but wrapping the existing ones through a really lightweight interface.

Which is exactly why I'm describing this as a trajectory interface, and not a trajectory library, and suggesting that it be a plugin-able interface which we can use to give all of these different implementations a common API.
(of course those lightweight plugins need to reside somewhere)

Having a lightweight interface is a requirement that is independent of loading code a runtime vs loading code at compile time.  However, loading code at runtime requires a bit more tooling, and makes it harder to reuse the code in a different setup.  A library is still the easiest way to share and reuse code across different systems.  Also, when you can resolve problems at compile time, that is generally preferred to solving problems at runtime.  So, I guess for this project I'm still missing the usecase that justifies/requires the use of loading code at runtime. Could you elaborate a bit more on who the users will be of these tools, and how they will use them?

So, I guess for this project I'm still missing the usecase that justifies/requires the use of loading code at runtime. Could you elaborate a bit more on who the users will be of these tools, and how they will use them?

Well if the library is being used by a controller, and the controllers are dynamically-loaded, then either the controllers need to depend on this library of trajectory wrapper implementations or they need to be dynamically-loadable. It simply decouples the dependencies.

It seems okay if a controller that needs trajectories depends on a library of trajectory implementations. In the end, you can't get away from that dependency; it'll either be a compile time dependency or a run time dependency.  So I'm still not sure what we're gaining by moving to runtime plugins. Sorry to keep pushing on this one, I'd love to get a better understanding of the motivation behind the design.
Currently, I can't see any need on my side for loading/switching various interpolation methods on runtime. I still like the idea though.

Having dynamically loadable interpolation and control methods would allow to create new flavours of controllers by just writing a launcher. Otherwise we will need to implement each combination as a separate controller (e.g. interpolation_A_control_method_B_controller, interpolation_B_control_method_B_controller, interpolation_A_control_method_A_controller etc.).
It seems okay if a controller that needs trajectories depends on a library of trajectory implementations. In the end, you can't get away from that dependency;

Except with a plugin-based interface the controllers themselves only need to depend on the interface, and not the interpolation implementations. That way one person can write a controller, and an unconnected person can write an interpolator, and then a third person can use both without having to create a new controller. It also allows simple and lightweight controller configuration as
I think there is a big need for a trajectory interface, and I see the gain in giving it plugin support, for the same combinatorial explosion reason given by
. The extra tooling effort will be worth it. Further, if a usecase prefers to have a build-time dependency, you can always choose to not use runtime loading and link to a particular library.

Otherwise we will need to implement each combination as a separate controller (e.g. interpolation_A_control_method_B_controller, interpolation_B_control_method_B_controller, interpolation_A_control_method_A_controller etc.).

I'm not quite convinced we need run time plugins for this either - that adds a small additional amount of complexity to an already complex controller framework. Instead, could we not have each controller have a build dependency on all the available interpolation methods, and then choose which one a controller uses based on a run time parameter/argument? I'm assuming we won't have
named 5 possible ones but will we really have the time to implement lots of different ones?

I prefer runtime plugins - makes it easier to test out different combinations easily. If we had a particular solution for trajectory interpolation and decided to just use that (which might not be a bad idea either), we could have just gone with it. Failing that, I would certainly prefer runtime plugins. Hopefully, we can converge on one library for this but the plugin will keep things flexible in the meantime.

I'm looking forward to using this, but I'd like to request that we settle on an interpolation interface which works for most basic use-cases.  I propose that at the controller runtime level, the interface consumes position and velocity vectors of the current state and returns position, velocity, and acceleration vectors of the target state.
As for the plugin/library discussion, I feel like it would be best to just to just settle on the Reflexxes library until someone makes a strong case for using something else.
looks pretty nice when compared to the old

In keeping it more simple for the controller writers, I feel it would be easier to just link it in.  Else, you have to be fairly clear that you now have to worry about 2 layers of plugins, the interpolating layer, and the controller layer.  Once we actually have people using different interpolators for controllers it would be easy to update everything to plugins.
I'm posting here an extended variant of a comment made on the robot control sig. I'm currently working on an implementation of the
that should be robot-agnostic, and trajectory-representation-agnostic. It's not finished yet, but it would be nice to have some feedback on how the trajectory interface is looking.
In order to support a new trajectory representation, you only need to provide an implementation of a
class, that conforms to an expected inteface (expected as in generic programming interface, not OO programming interface). An example follows:
, if it makes sense to your application.

For some segment representations (Reflexxes-based?), the start state might be of little significance, but I think it does no harm to have it there, as other representations such as splines do need it.
A trajectory is no more than a container (preferably a sequence container) with segments sorted according to their start time, like so:
At this point, there are some useful bits of functionality that you can leverage without writing additional code:
For the specific case of joint trajectories, where the state is a multi-dof
triplet, there are additional methods that allow you to populate a trajectory from a
message. This is work-in-progress, but if your segment's
, you should be able to do the following:
What I have described so far is the heart of the
. If we want to have a plugin-based trajectory representation, it should suffice to make the plugin base class conform to the interface of the
and I think this fulfills much of this issue. I'm cleaning up old issues so closing this for now. Feel free to reopen if desired.
I just want to note that the
is a joint-space interpolator. We could repoen this issue in a later time if and when there is interest and available manpower for Cartesian (or other types) of interpolators.
The generic trajectory interface discussed earlier in this thread is implemented and used by the
. It could be used for Cartesian interpolation as well. All that needs to be done is define the appropriate State and Segment types. The interface currently lives

So, I guess for this project I'm still missing the usecase that justifies/requires the use of loading code at runtime. Could you elaborate a bit more on who the users will be of these tools, and how they will use them?
It seems okay if a controller that needs trajectories depends on a library of trajectory implementations. In the end, you can't get away from that dependency;

Otherwise we will need to implement each combination as a separate controller (e.g. interpolation_A_control_method_B_controller, interpolation_B_control_method_B_controller, interpolation_A_control_method_A_controller etc.).

issue_title: Use socket timeouts on all redis connections
issue_contents: I initially believed it was possible to get around this by properly shutting down each redis socket using socket.shutdown. Once you shut the socket down, RedisListenerThread exits gracefully in about 30 seconds.

However, a side-effect is that since socket.shutdown takes a bit of time, and redis.Connection.disconnect() is not exactly atomic, we sometimes try and close an already closed socket (and bad things happen). Currently, we are handling all raised exceptions in a hackish way (
). If we use socket timeouts everywhere, this will become unnecessary.
Also found relevant bug report at py-redis:

If we introduce socket timeouts, we get rid of a few hacks (RedisConnectionChecker, manually disconnecting the connection pool, calling disconnect on a connection multiple times). On the flip side, we'll have to introduce a few hacks to work around the upstream issue above. Pushing a fix upstream is possible, but time-consuming, and I am not even sure what the correct behavior is supposed to be.
Since the current behavior in hydro-devel is acceptable (
got fixed with socket shutdowns), I am marking this issue as wontfix. We can revisit it sometime in the future as necessary.

issue_title: Gateway cpu usage high
issue_contents: Seeing high usage (60% per gateway) on piyush's simulation. Get the chatter concert usage for a good reference and then consider attacking the problem. Gateways should be well under 10%.
In case the chatter concert usage is high as well, there may be some possibility that this was a result of all the changes I made last month.
Another possibility is that I set gateway_watch_loop_period to 1s
, but this should be true for turtle concert as well, from where I ripped off the file.

Interesting point here, only the concert gateway is busy. So that leads me to conclude it's not the runtime activity of the gateway, rather it must be getting busy handling callbacks (from the conductor probably). I need to check:
Conductor v1 usage is pretty high as well. Not quite as high, but still high.
It's not spamming it, it's only 1 remote_gateway_info service call per second.
It's also not intensive - that callback only runs for <10ms every second, which couldn't possibly raise the cpu rates we're seeing.

So my assumption is wrong. Something internally is blowing up the cpu and it is the runtime. Which now reminds me that I had all sorts of exponentially increasing cpu problems the more rules there were for a gateway to handle. This gateway is handling alot of pull rules, 5 for each robot on top of the flips etc.
For reference, the concert gateway running chatter concert on my work pc runs at 17-35%.
substituting the appropriate delay and pid
Actually removing all those pulls (12 to 3) didn't change the cpu usage at all, still 17-35%.
Time diffs for the functions in the
That last one is coming from
Almost all this time is consumed in the scope of this

takes about 50ms. And if there are 8x flipped in connections to check, then it takes the 400-500ms we are looking at. Chatter concert is simple, this is going to die in a complicated scenario with many flipins.
Not actually doing any work here, just validating the existing connections, but I expect the serialization is being greedy.
do you have an idea of how to better do this? Is it necessary...I've removed it but are there possible situations we have to be careful of?
in detail and am just assuming its serializing/deserializing heavily for 50ms. Perhaps there is more to the story there.
Well. I just did a rather poor implementation of
.Additionally, that else block is really nasty, as it tries to mark the flip as accepted even if it might be marked already.
Should be an easy fix, and should give considerable runtime improvement. I'll submit a PR later tonight.
This has gotten pushed to tomorrow. Should be first thing on my list.
for the gazebo_segbot_concert scenario has gone down from 0.45 to 0.0005 on my machine. See PR
There are still a ton of steps that can be taken to clean up the base gateway infrastructure, both in terms of readability and efficiency. We'll get to them as time permits

issue_title: Not able to open socket socket 0 at host: X.X.X.X at port 50001
issue_contents: The error in the title showed up in the UR10 control panel info while trying to send a goal to the arm (such as in test_move.py).

We are able to update the payload without any error. Also $rostopic hz is 125 Hz for arm topics. It should be noted that there were no controllers found running : $rosservice call /controller_manager/list_controllers {}
Changed the port though ur_ros_wrapper.cpp - same issue with different port from 50001
Thank you very much in advance for helping with this problem.
how you start the driver, which launch files, in which order, etc.
Further: are you running this in a Virtual Machine? If not, does your computer have multiple network interfaces? Do you have a firewall enabled?
Changed the port though ur_ros_wrapper.cpp - same issue with different port from 50001
don't do that, this is all configurable using the launch parameters supported by the launch files, so don't go and change any source files.
PS: "Help please!!!" is not needed. We'll be notified of your issue as soon as you open it, and we'll respond as soon as we have time.
Thank you for the fast response!
No firewall, its a clean Ubuntu 14.04 running on a clean laptop (Intel, SSD).
Same issue with regular network connection and with a cross-cable.
The following lines were suppose to work with the said hardware and software versions:

It seems that changing the "reverse_port" in the terminal did not effect the port number showed by the control panel of the robot. Only by editing ur_ros_wrapper.cpp the port actually changed (just trying to isolate the issue).
First: those are not copy-pastes from your terminal. Especially the exact form of the
is important. Could you copy-paste an example of that please (you can change the IP if you want)?
Unfortunately I wont be able to get near the UR for the next few days.

These lines are exact except the IP and Port.  The IP chosen is 192.168.1.10 and port 50001 as an example.  Tried it with and without the reverse_port command. The IP was set manually when the cross-cable was used and set automatically when connected through the network.
by the way- same issue when sending commands using rviz (obviously)
Its hard to imagine that this is a network issue.  I'll add the output of netstat -antu as soon as I can.
No point in speculating until we know more about your network setup / open ports.
Note that you don't need to supply the
argument. It's got a good default already.

I love speculations, especially with problem solving. I googled netstat -antu and figured no other option then the firewall. Loaded the Ubuntu and yes, it was on ;-| . It was odd since through the ports 3001-3002 it was able to send commands to the robot (changing the payload indeed updated the control panel payload configuration) so didn't even think to recheck the firewall's status. Moreover, on execution of test_move.py, the control panel printed out "Program driverProg started" before the error massage.
In Linux the port numbers are divided into three ranges:
Well Known Ports: those from 0 through 1023.
Dynamic and/or Private Ports: those from 49152 through 65535
That is why I tried changing the port number under 49000 (3999, which didnt work with reverse_port btw), the same category of the ports that did work (30001-30003).
How come only some of the TCP/IP packets can be passed through the firewall?
Resolved (not verified but... it is).  Thank you again for helping with this issue.
I love speculations, especially with problem solving
sure, but only based on facts. And those were missing.
I googled netstat -antu and figured no other option then the firewall. Loaded the Ubuntu and yes, it was on
ok, well that's your problem then.
It was odd since through the ports 3001-3002 it was able to send commands to the robot
well, that is not totally unexpected: (consumer) firewalls typically allow traffic
of the machine by default, but block everything coming from the outside.
Moreover, on execution of test_move.py, the control panel printed out "Program driverProg started" before the error massage.
Again, not so strange, as that is uploaded
That is why I tried changing the port number under 49000 (3999, which didnt work with reverse_port btw), the same category of the ports that did work (30001-30003).
There is no reason to change that port at all (unless you have something already using
or are setting up a multi-arm config), and whether it's an ephemeral port or not does not matter either.
How come only some of the TCP/IP packets can be passed through the firewall?
I believe this should now be clear.
I'm closing this as I have the impression that you've solved your issue.
Please re-open if you have any further problems (with this same issue, otherwise open a new issue).
I encountered a similar issue but I resolved it by resetting the firewall. Hope that could help anyone who may encounter a similar problem.

issue_title: kuka krl_file_parser support
issue_contents: Based on comment from Hemes in
[2], I'm proposing the development of a
support here, enabling translating generated trajectory from motion planner in moveit architecture (OMPL or descartes) into kuka-executable

[1] file, so that we can execute the generated robot motion by copying and pasting KRL file (via usb or direct upload) to KRC controller and execute them by T1 (hand-held safe mode for kuka) or Auto mode.

For application without the need of sensoring and live-feedback, I think this might be a good and safe way to unleash the power of  ros and moveit! to broader industrial robot user and researcher community, as RSI and MxAutomation [issue
)[1]. And I assume for industrial users with the worry of having different trajectories every time they use Moveit OMPL for same target and goal (check the

(21'33'') from Shaun Edwards at ROSCon2015 [3]) can be mitigated by using this method. Users can save their moveit-generated motion from offline planning in ros, without having to setup connection between their ros-server and real robot controller (and expensive controller interface controller as well), allowing them to preform the same moveit trajectory for specific goal every time they run it using the file. This parser might be good for simple motion demonstration without live-feedback, and also allow users to exploit ros moveit's power with no intention or condition for having required vendor-based software and hardware.
[1], a very comprehensive (a bit old, butr still working really well) manual can be found here[4].
Happy to hear opinions and suggestions. (Also welcome to check and contribute the the discussion in our
, thanks for opening this issue here.
First: I believe what you are describing / asking for would be a post processor or code generator instead of a parser. The former would
KRL to send it to a controller, while the latter would
That aside, having a post processor targeting KUKA would definitely be of interest, and I believe we have a good starting point over at
. The developers of RoboDK have contributed all the post processors available in RoboDK and have been very responsive to suggestions and bug reports.

The idea is to wrap the post-processors in a ROS node that exposes appropriate services and actions to make it possible to transform generic ROS representations for trajectories into controller-specific programs. I think you've already found some discussion about that over at
A few notes about some specific things.
And I assume for industrial users with the worry of having different trajectories every time they use Moveit OMPL for same target and goal (check the
(21'33'') from Shaun Edwards at ROSCon2015 [3]) can be mitigated by using this method.

This is definitely an approach to improve determinism and predictability. An alternative could be to exploit a caching system between MoveIt and planning consumers that could remove the need to replan for every request completely, provided start and end states (and other relevant pieces of the robot's state) are identical / close enough to a stored one.

Users can save their moveit-generated motion from offline planning in ros, without having to setup connection between their ros-server and real robot controller (and expensive controller interface controller as well), allowing them to preform the same moveit trajectory for specific goal every time they run it using the file.
Very important here is to note that you obviously lose the replanning and obstacle avoidance capabilities whenever re-used plans are used.
: would you be ok with centralising the discussion about code generation/post processors, and close this issue in favour of
: Thanks for your reply and discussion.
I wrote this commit before I joined the discussion in
. Sure I will close this issue and recommend whoever shares the interest in this to move to robodk_postprocessors.
issue_quotes: And I assume for industrial users with the worry of having different trajectories every time they use Moveit OMPL for same target and goal (check the
(21'33'') from Shaun Edwards at ROSCon2015 [3]) can be mitigated by using this method.

Users can save their moveit-generated motion from offline planning in ros, without having to setup connection between their ros-server and real robot controller (and expensive controller interface controller as well), allowing them to preform the same moveit trajectory for specific goal every time they run it using the file.

issue_title: Add service to MotoROS to retrieve true link lengths and joint limits
issue_contents: This is really just a suggestion, but would be very nice to have.
Perhaps we could add a service to MotoROS that would allow clients to retrieve information about the kinematics of the robot that the MotoROS server is running on. In particular, I'm thinking:

The driver could then expose a ROS service that would translate the information returned by MotoROS into ROS datatypes (TBD). For accessing the specific parameters on the robot controller we could employ the same scheme as is currently used with the

Depending on how MotoROS makes this information available, we could even see whether it would be possible to generate a skeleton urdf/xacro macro using some tool basing it on the data coming from the controller.
This could make adding support for new robot variants somewhat easier.
I am definitely in favor of this. But, I won't be able to implement it quickly. Also, I expect that
is busy until at least mid-September. But, I think one of us could probably implement something around the end of Sept.
Depending on how MotoROS makes this information available, we could even see whether it would be possible to generate a skeleton urdf/xacro macro
Can you elaborate on how you like this data presented? I'm thinking it would just be a new command message on the state-server.
But, I won't be able to implement it quickly. Also, I expect that
is busy until at least mid-September. But, I think one of us could probably implement something around the end of Sept.
I would offer to do some of the development, but the bulk of it would probably be retrieving the parameters, and that is something I cannot do.
Perhaps I can see whether I can do something on the simple message and motoman_driver side.
Depending on how MotoROS makes this information available, we could even see whether it would be possible to generate a skeleton urdf/xacro macro
Can you elaborate on how you like this data presented? I'm thinking it would just be a new command message on the state-server.
Yes, it would be a request-reply sequence probably added to the state server (doesn't really matter though which server it ends up being).
I was more referring to whether it'd be in the form of DH parameters, no specific notation or modeling at all, or in the form of transforms -- as ROS uses.
The latter would obviously make things very easy for ROS consumers, but as there are users of MotoROS outside the ROS context, it might not be the most suitable option.
might be something to take into account here.
Is this something we could start discussing again

I do think that doing anything complex is an over kill.  To my knowledge, it is very rare that a robot is calibrated and the arm link lengths are modified in the process.  Making reference to the spec sheet should be fine in most cases.

If we put it in the MotoROS driver, it should be super simple, just spitting out the none zero length in order and not try to explicitly build the model.  It would require the modification the Parameter Extraction Library since Yaskawa will not publish restricted parameters informations.

Otherwise, I would recommend making a separate application that would make a standard URDF file from the all.prm file and make it available to end users.  The problem with that is to make sure to address the various robot models and maintaining it over time.  At this time, I do not believe that this issue can justify the required development and making a URDF for a new robot only takes a couple of hours and most of the effort is related to the 3D model work, not the actual URDF file.
It doesn't need to be very complex. Just returning the nr of links, their order and link lengths should suffice. Perhaps in a "graph" based format (ie:
It would be a simple SimpleMessage service with an overlaying ROS API.
All proprietary access to parameters stays on the controller that way.
Stand-alone applications need additional maintenance, and that may be overhead we're not willing to pay at this time.
I do believe that for users to be able to verify that the URDF they're (trying) to use is correct wrt their robot would be a great service.

I can add this into the next update. There are a couple outstanding issues that I'm waiting on some feedback before I implement the next update. So, I'm hoping to have something implemented in 1-2 weeks.
Can you provide an example struct of how you thing the message(s) should be organized?
adds a service that returns D-H parameters.
The ROS side would have to be added, but MotoROS has been extended with this service in
Tracking the ROS API side in

But, I won't be able to implement it quickly. Also, I expect that
is busy until at least mid-September. But, I think one of us could probably implement something around the end of Sept.

issue_title: Question about IKFast & UR arms
issue_contents: Does there exist a working implementation of OpenRave's IKFast system for UR10 & UR5 arms? Just curious before I start hacking away on one!
We don't have one for a bare arm (all of ours have an end-effector on them).  I can say that ikfast is an order of magnitude faster than KDL.

I see. And yes, KDL is causing some difficulties within MoveIt. Do you know if there's an available IKFast for MoveIt? I saw the moveit_ikfast package, but is there any kind of configuration I'll need to do for the UR10?
It's probably easiest to re-run the moveit setup assistant on the existing package.  The drop down for kinematic chains should show any/all IK plugins.
file to point to the fast IK plugin package.  The fanuc packages make use of ikfast (see
Ah ok, so I do have to configure/create one for the UR10 arm then.
: does it have to be ikfast based? The repository already contains IK/FK packages for both the UR5 and the UR10. In principle I'd say they should offer the same (or even better, see
) level of functionality, if we can get the issues that some users have reported cleared up (
It would perhaps be more efficient to try and fix that, than starting from scratch with IKFast (which can be difficult for the URs).
there is already a commented block that would use the analytical IK solver from the
package (it's also there for the UR10).
You can try it, but as

mentioned this solver will return IK solutions that are within the full joint range [-2Pi...2Pi] so that it only works with the ur_description with the limited option set to false, with which MoveIt! cannot plan in a reasonalbe amount of planning time....

There have been tests with IKFast and the universal arms a while ago (groovy times), but the solver did not return correct solutions in some cases. This was actually the reason why work on an analytical IK solver has been started by
Btw, you can find the IKFast related works
. I don't think they will compile under indigo, but if you want to have a look at it....
If that's the only problem, wouldn't it be easy to wrap the analytical solver in ur_kinematics to return only solutions in [-Pi...Pi] or [0...2Pi]?
: I'm not really sure that the issue really is with the
bit of obligatory code in them (
), as all IKFast plugins do. I figured
would be much faster in fixing this, so I never looked any further.
We don't have one for a bare arm (all of ours have an end-effector on them) [..]

I've always thought it made sense to create IKFast plugins for just the kinematic chain from base to end-of-arm, excluding any tooling. That would then make it possible to re-use them in any situation. Including the EOAT in your IKFast plugin seems like a strange thing to do?
Conclusion from this discussion: IK/FK exists for UR arms. But are broken and slow in unlimited joint space and does not work in limited joint space.
Actions: fix the IK/FK so that it's better in unlimited joint space? is that an inherent problem of the algorithm being used or the programming is wrong for it?

Should we be porting this to IKFast if that works, or looking for different optimization algorithms? The baxter videos I've seen seem to get things right nearly 100% of the time and execute within 2 seconds. Is it possible we can achieve that kind of performance with the UR arms, or perhaps the Baxter videos are a farce..
Conclusion from this discussion: IK/FK exists for UR arms. But are broken and slow in unlimited joint space and does not work in limited joint space.
are far from slow. They might be a little slower than IKFast generated plugins, but not much, if at all. The only issue with them is that they
to ignore joint limits, and only when a

This is used in the rare singularity where joints 2, 3, and 4 are parallel

issue_title: motoman_driver: driver flags trajectory completion too soon
issue_contents: The fs100 controller driver seems to return a completion result for a trajectory even though the robot is still moving towards the goal position.  This issue was observed when I sent a new trajectory with the "execute" method of the moveit move_group interface.  The driver error message complained about the start state differing from the current state and then the node running the move_group interface would quit.  My application only uses locking motion methods (move() and execute() ), which should theoretically prevent situations where a new trajectory is sent while another trajectory is being consumed.
A catkin package that can help reproduced this behaviour has been created in the following repo
.  It also contains instructions for setup and execution.
, Do either of you have time to track this down?

Actually, I think this behavior may be caused by MoveIt's trajectory planner, rather than the FS100 controller.  When I dig into the issue, it seems like the internal state MoveIt's trajectory planner uses for the trajectory start-state is different than MoveIt's own "Current Joint State" feedback.  When motion plans are issued quickly back-to-back, the trajectory planner seems to use out-dated position data, and thus triggers the error described above.
I have been able to reproduce this error, both on a physical robot (Motoman FS100 controller) and using the robot-agnostic industrial_robot_simulator.  Note that I have only tested in Groovy so far.

that demonstrates this behavior.  Load up any MoveIt package, then run the script to issue a set of back-to-back motion commands.  In my testing, for all planned moves other than the first (which is a special-case), the start position of a MoveIt-planned trajectory does not match the Current Joint Position also reported by MoveIt.
I have verified this behavior in hydro.  On further testing, it seems this behavior is only seen when using the separate
call, the robot behaves as expected.  This explains why we haven't typically seen this before, since most of our code uses the single
I have logged a detailed MoveIt Bug Report (
).  See that bug for further discussions.  We'll close this bug after verifying a MoveIt fix.
I'm closing this as I believe this is no longer a problem - at least not the problem that
There is / may still be a problem with the driver flagging completion of trajectories too quickly, but that is related to multi-group motion and is being addressed in

issue_title: Design the World Model
issue_contents: The robot's image or mental model of the world.

The image of the world around us, which we carry in our head, is just a model. Nobody in his head imagines all the world, government or country. He has only selected concepts, and relationships between them, and uses those to represent the real system.
Navigation decisions and actions are made based on this model.
As shown below, the world model is populated with information coming from sensing, perception, and mapping; and supplies information to the navigation sub-modules.
In order to guide our design decisions on the World Model, let's take a closer look at what are the various kinds of inputs and outputs.
Let's consider the modules that provide information to the world model

The perception module provides input to the world model mainly to account for changes in the environment from both moving objects but also stationary objects with dynamic attributes, i.e. a traffic light.
Currently, moving objects are mostly accounted for by the obstacle layer of
which process the raw output of a laser scanner.

The map server provides a priori information of the environment, mostly of stationary objects, in the form of a map. Maps can also contain dynamic information about some of these objects, i.e. traffic, road closures, etc.
Currently, the map server is only capable of processing and providing grid/cell-based (metric) types of map representations.
Let's consider the consumers of the information contained in the world model, aka the clients.
Clients operate on different length-scales and use different layers or aspects of the world model.
Can operate on a road network, topology map, or global map (sub-sampled occupancy grid or k-d tree).
These are coupled with the map representation being used.
Currently, only planners that operate on a costmap are supported.
Operates on a higher resolution local map representation, for example, an occupancy grid.
Attempts to follow the global path while correcting for obstacles in a dynamic environment. Provides the control inputs to the robot.
. This has its own internal representation of the world (
) with direct access to raw sensor data.
Currently, motion primitives do not interact with the world model. A pull-request (
) is open that would add collision checking.
In ROS1 recovery, both the global and local costmap based representations were passed to the world model.
Design a world / environmental model for 2D navigation.
Summarizing the design improvements discussed above:
Given the extension of the change, we'll have to implement the design in multiple phases.
In the first phase, we can separate the world model from the clients and make them separate nodes.

In the second phase, we can define the new modules and port the current costmap based world model. Below is a high-level diagram, the components are explained below. The main point of this phase is to remove the dependency between the core representation and the type of client, we do this by defining some
that translate the information of the Core into something useful to the client. Similarly, we also define

On the following phases, we can extend this by introducing other map formats (beyond grid-based maps) and perception pipelines. We also support multiple internal representations. Eventually, we might have something like this:

The core representation is module rich enough to represent the world with enough expressiveness for at least doing navigation. In an ideal case, this could be an internal simulator where we can ask anything about the world. By querying this internal simulator, we can build a structure needed by a navigation sub-module.

We might want to experiment with different types of core representations with different levels of expressiveness. We can initially use costmaps but eventually move to scene-graphs that support a semantic interface.
Additionally, multiple representations might be appropriate i.e. Robot-centric, World-centric.
The planner plugin extracts information from the core representation to create the structure needed by the planner.
The control plugin extracts information from the core to create a useful structure for a controller/local planner.
Gets the map from the server and populates the core.
Gets low level (sensor data streams) or high level (objects with meta-data) and populates / updates the core.

On a high level I don't see anything here that I see as a show stopper, but it also seems like this design is trying to bite out alot of things to be generally and extendable to everybody. I might think about reducing scope to get something out there that works and is relatable to existing technologies to build off of.

Only bit of input I'd add is that in the "core representation" I believe that there is no single correct way of representing the space (costmap, grid map, traversability map, etc) and should instead be a combination of all of them - such that the costmap is really a vector of of these items stacked on top of each other. Different applications can utilize different representations as they like but the data filled in populates the costmap, and the traversability map, and the ... based on whatever the application warrants.
From talking about this again this week I had another thought which I'm sure others have thought about but maybe not in words:

We would like to not have to redo different planning and controlling algorithms into different ones for different representations of costmaps. Rather than trying to make something like templating everywhere and trying to make everyone happy and readable, I'm thinking a good thought would be to have adaptors.

For example right now we're going costmap -> planner. Now we might go costmap -> adaptor -> planner, similarly with traversability map -> adaptor -> planner. This lets us generalize all the new planning and control algorithms independent of the implementation of the world model (making those by itself is hard without having to deal with lots of templates and thinking about ramifications across multiple representations).

Then we have a finite set of adaptors we need to build to represent the different models we'd like (costmaps, traversability, elevation, etc) who's job is to take the value of the neighboring cells and apply the vehicle kinematics and dynamics to give back a response "ok" "not ok" "unknown" or other options. The example adaptor for a costmap would be to change the 0-255 to those return types. Elevation map would apply the vehicle dynamics or maximum gradients to return the same type of information.

Now all planners or controller that work for 1 will work for all as long as they can run with   "ok" "not ok" "unknown" or other options and be extendable easily for sampling based planners by creating methods in the adaptor to get the value at a certain location in global frame coordinates which the adaptor could project into a costmap cell, voxel grid pose, or elevation gradient.
adaptors ... who's job is to take the value of the neighboring cells and apply the vehicle kinematics and dynamics to give back a response "ok" "not ok" "unknown"

Are you envisioning the output of the adaptor in this example as a sort of simplified costmap where each cell is filled with a ok, not ok, or unknown value. Or are you thinking more that the client feeds a trajectory to the adaptor and the adaptor returns the evaluation of the trajectory as a ok, not ok, unknown value?
This pushes the knowledge of the vehicle dynamics to the world model (adaptors) instead of the algorithms. How confident are you that this is the right place for that knowledge?

I had thought of having input and output adaptors as well, but I was thinking it could result N^2 adaptors since we theoretically could want to convert from any representation to any other. I expect it wouldn't be so bad in practice since many conversions are probably not useful.

Based on your feedback, I was imagining something like this below. We have a collection of representations. Adaptors to convert incoming data to those representations as needed. Clients that either get data directly from the representation they need or from an adaptor if there is a mismatch in the representation provided and the type they need.
Thanks for making that diagram, I'm certainly a pretty lazy guy when it comes to visualizations :)

First off, I'm not sure why you have a separate pipeline for laser scans, that defeats the purpose of having a general purpose world model to take in arbitrary sensors to generate a view of the world. I'd recommend completely scrapping that, I don't see anything special about a laser scanner requiring that type of pipeline within the world model. If you'd like to use it as a safety sensor with zones, that should be up stream of this since that's not generalized and many robots today don't use them anymore or have a different sensor suite.

What I think should be happening is a similar way of how it's done today. There's a set of optional plugins to buffer arbitrary sensor information  (scans, images, depth maps, radar, sonar, etc) when does stuff of interest for that sensor, and inserts it into the map. I'm not thinking greatly into how to generalize those plugins for different plugins. In practice, I dont think you'll find a way to generalize that. A costmap is binning a depth map for collision avoidance, while an elevation map will use them over time to generate an ellipsoid curve or something are very different operations on the same sensor data. Those plugins for buffering and inserting data into their representation are probably representation specific.

Looking on the other side however, we have our [representation A] which needs to be utilized by the local/global planners to navigate. In the case of the elevation map, the Z coordinate becomes meaningful so we can't just talk about 2D X-Y coordinates anymore. The planner or controller will say "give me the neighbors" and its then up to the adaptor to say "I'm an elevation map, therefore my neighbors are in a 3D 8-directional curves" or "I'm a costmap, I just need to give the cells on either side of me", and return that information to the planner or controller to do their will with an ask for more things as needed.

This lets us do 2D or 3D representations but allow the same algorithms for local and global planning to operate (and moreover, would work for drones as well). When the adaptors return their neighbors, its up to the adaptor's knowledge of the robot dynamics and mechanics to assign them some set of finite states that can be generalized across all representations. That might include OK, not OK, unknown, not recommended, etc but as long as all of the algorithms are built to work with those same finite states, then whatever the representation is, it'll work. And the adaptors can use the Robot class to get those relevant dynamics. For a diff drive robot, its just all OK like in navigation1, but for an ackermann car or an elevation map on a legged robot, that may not be valid

I think what you are refering to as adaptor is what I have as a plugin below. We can later discuss the best pattern but the idea is the same, this block's goal is to translate the information available on the Core Representation and express it in something the client needs.

Yes that's what I'm thinking, with the only exception that the "Sensing and Perception" isn't 1 plugin, but also a series of plugins, but I think that may have just been represented that way for brevity.

Each representation will have an associated plugin that converts its values into the limited-enum types and is responsible for answering the query from the controller/planner "give me the neighbors" and "give me the value at (x,y,z)".
I'm not sure why you have a separate pipeline for laser scans

It was meant to represent a possibility. If a sensor could output data directly in representation format, it could talk directly to the model. But that's a stupid idea in context. I was playing with the idea that everything could be a ROS node; each representation could be a node and each adaptor as well.
I think what you are refering to as adaptor is what I have as a plugin below.

Do we want to be able to chain adaptors/plugins? As in, there is a plugin that provides data from the representation, but there is a second plugin that grabs the output of the first plugin and provides it in a different way

Each representation will have an associated plugin that converts its values into the limited-enum types and is responsible for answering the query from the controller/planner "give me the neighbors" and "give me the value at (x,y,z)".

So we'd need to figure out the queries that can be used by many algorithms. We'd then end up with an output plugin per class of algorithm, where a class could be graph search algorithms like A*, Dijkstra, D* etc.
Well at the end of the day all the graph search algorithms are going to ask for neighbors, the sampling based planners will ask for the result at a certain position, I'm not
certain what optimization based planners will ask for, but that's overkill for 2D navigation as far as I know. If not, we can find out what thematically they ask for.

I think plugin API implementing neighbors, position in global frame (then it should internally find the value of its representation i.e. costmap would look for X-Y cell index and then the location in the array), and random sample to start with. We can always extend it if this is the way you also think makes sense. It was just a suggestion

Grid Maps exists and does a number of things. I haven't done too much work with it myself but from what I've been reading it looks like everything costmap_2d does, this does as well. We might want to consider that as an option to completely replace costmap 2d for a ground up rebuild.
Closing the issue, it seems we're sticking with the current costmap design for now.
issue_quotes: The image of the world around us, which we carry in our head, is just a model. Nobody in his head imagines all the world, government or country. He has only selected concepts, and relationships between them, and uses those to represent the real system.
adaptors ... who's job is to take the value of the neighboring cells and apply the vehicle kinematics and dynamics to give back a response "ok" "not ok" "unknown"
I'm not sure why you have a separate pipeline for laser scans
I think what you are refering to as adaptor is what I have as a plugin below.

Each representation will have an associated plugin that converts its values into the limited-enum types and is responsible for answering the query from the controller/planner "give me the neighbors" and "give me the value at (x,y,z)".
contents_details_more: Ideally, we would encapsulate all sensor processing in the perception module.
World model would in some cases only receive higher-level descriptions of objects.
Enable servicing from multiple maps (stitching multiple maps)
Map representation is to some extent planner-dependent, therefore compatible map representations and planners might need to be selected at launch time.
For incompatible types, do we support transformation between types?
Some generalization might be possible if we consider maps as graphs and use planners that search on graphs.

For 2D navigation of a mobile platform, we could consider Combinatorial methods as graph construction techniques which output is then used by a graph search algorithm. We might want to consider this as a capability of the World Model, i.e. produce different types of graphs.

Adding the cost to a cell in the world model is used to encode some type of information, for example, to avoid possible collision given robot footprint or define a region preference. We might, however, want to handle this differently.
See Map Server section for some other questions related to the planner.
Extend interface to support other local planners (
Define the types of services needed by motion primitives, only for collision checking?
Define the types of services needed to support recovery, currently only identified clearing the structure (
Support different levels of navigation, i.e. unstructured (no specific rules or reference path / lane), structured (predefined rules), etc.
Add support for different types of planners and controllers.
Consolidate the world model. Define a clean interface. Avoid code replication.
Improve the integration of perception pipelines.
Create a design that can be extended to a multi-robot scenario with distributed parts of the world-model.
What other core representations are we interested in eventually supporting? Scene graph, costmap, etc.

We need to address the map-planner dependency issue. If the map server provides the map representation on a given format (i.e. elevation map) but the planner uses costmap, what component does the conversion?

Topological maps. What are the use cases? As a replacement to metric map or addition? Annotated with information on how to navigate from one place to another? Is the navigation goal defined as a node on this map?
What is the interface between the world model client and the controller?
Map server to update in runtime the dynamic aspects of the map? Traffic given some external traffic monitoring system.
Perception could also update dynamic aspects?
Extract the world model from the clients and encapsulate into separate nodes. World models will be client dependent. No new additional functionality.
Sensing-to-Core plugin to use laser scan and update obstacle layer in
Map-to-Core to use map to fill static layer in
Global planner plugin to get master layer of

I'm not sure I understand the issue here. I see dwb_controller does increase CPU usage to 100% when the robot is actually moving, which is somewhat to be expected as dwb_controller is running in a control loop updating about 10x/second. Here are the things I noticed:

pretty much speaks all what I'm noticing. Another thing is that the controller rate is decreasing over time. Since the CPU usage for controller is maxed out at around 100% (because it's a sequential procedure I presume?), my explanation toward decreasing rate of the controller is that the computational requirement is growing.

I have no hard evidence, but a very short prediction path like the default setting with only 10Hz should uses much less CPU. My guesses is based on the experiences with ROS1 navigation. When I'm using the same hardware rig, one particular case was I can run ROS1 TEB planner at 10Hz, with a prediction length of 4m&(0.1m/pix), and with global planner re-planning at 0.4Hz at the same time. TEB utilizes a nonlinear optimization solver on a car-like vehicle (constrained problem), which should demand much more calculations than DWA. So the 40% CPU usage in the beginning seems closer to my expectation. Again, these are only my instincts without any evidence.

issue_title: Slow robot if DWB missing performance requirements
issue_contents: DWB fails to meet the desired performance when running an un-optimized build resulting in instability in the control loop. It would be desirable for DWB to dynamically reduce commanded robot speeds to the point where it can be controlled stably to make it possible to run debug builds or, alternatively on machines with insufficient performance.
This should be configurable so that DWB can instead fail or ignore the problem at the desire of the user.
My suggestion is to rather print warnings if in capable to reach performance requirements. Inside of the controller server rather than the DWB plugin so that its general for any consumer code.
This however, as I found, is already implemented from our
implementation. When building a system, if you start seeing these warnings, there's something wrong and that should be addressed in development.

I'm going to close this ticket since if you're running your system so hot that this is happening, its a safety issue larger than just trying to throttle the controller rate. Throttling the controller rate on model predictive controllers (which TEB tangentially falls into) can actually be a critical failure resulting in collisions.
Rather than designing a safety mechanism specific to DWB, I'd rather leave it how it is.
Closing. If you disagree, we can reopen to continue discussing.

issue_contents: The include order for OMPL and catkin in ompl/CMakeLists.txt seems wrong to me. However, there are already two commits switching this around:

Thanks for that explanation. I do not have the motivation to push for this right now (too many MoveIt! emails already) so instead I just documented it and maybe someone in the future will pursue it
I will assume no one else does either. Please re-open if you want to work on this low-priority annoyance
, something to keep in mind for future OMPL Debian releases?
, where is this directory layout / naming convention documented? Does this apply to all Linux/Unix based systems?
where is this directory layout / naming convention documented?
Good question indeed. Actually, I'm not sure it is documented explicitly.
Or at least I don't have a reference at hand, unless you count
Does this apply to all Linux/Unix based systems?

The reasoning behind the nested layout is the exact problem we have above and to the best of my knowledge it exists throughout the Linux/Unix world: libraries don't want to pollute the ordering of include directories in case their install location coincides with other packages. In our case: make the dependent project include
in the position of  the OMPL include path, even though other include paths should come in between the two.
The important behavior many of the standard libs in the Linux world exhibit upstream, but ompl doesn't, is that they do not export
as include path, but some subfolder instead. Note that
Everything would be fine, if OMPL would add
as include directory and require users to include the headers as e.g.
. Personally I don't like that style, but it's common enough in standard packages.

two main obstacles I encountered on MacOS (w/r/t navigation, had to hack around other things in TB3 support packages):
<-- makecontext/getcontext corrupting stack. Rearranging headers solves this, but I still don't know why it works, just that bt_navigator stops crashing with header order changes.

obstacles have very high cost <-- I placed a cup on the floor and TB3 gives it a 6 foot cone of shame where it won't go anywhere near it. Trouble is, this was in a 10 foot x 11 foot room with a few obstacles (mostly in corners), so there was very little space TB3 was willing to navigate to, everywhere was marked as high cost and/or fatal cost. I tuned the parameters mentioned earlier (inflation_layer.cost_scaling_factor, inflation_layer.inflation_radius) as the default parameters were far too large for my use cases. I also had difficulty navigating in a larger room (10 foot wide hallway) and tuning these parameters improved every room I tested so far.
It isn't perfect (some collisions with wall, some occasional spinning in complex spaces) but it's significantly better at this point.

issue_contents: apparently the cameracalibrator.py runs out of memory after a while, when I'm calibrating. It continuosly grew on meory consumption, up to 3GB of my 4GB RAM, before it broke.
Does anybody know why this is happening? How can I fix this?
OpenCV Error: Insufficient memory (Failed to allocate 3612676 bytes) in OutOfMemoryError, file /home/pfaion/Downloads/opencv-2.4.9/modules/core/src/alloc.cpp, line 52
cv2.error: /home/pfaion/Downloads/opencv-2.4.9/modules/core/src/alloc.cpp:52: error: (-4) Failed to allocate 3612676 bytes in function OutOfMemoryError
How big are your images ? I believe it stores them in RAM which could explain this lack of memory.
I could not reproduce that at all: which version are you using ?
What cameras ? stereo/mono ? Which resolution ? Thx

Apparently the calibrator stores the images that it receives while calibrating in a queue or something (?). The calibration took quite long... several minutes I think. So it received a lot of images in that time, that were all queued in the RAM for whatever reason.

When I kill the image-stream after it started calibrating, the error won't occur and the calibration outputs all the data, but crashes in the end, because it is not able to find the stream again. This solved the problem for me, but should not be necessary!

I am running Ubuntu 14.04 and ros indigo, working with an ASUS Xtion PRO Live, and doing the calibration for RGB and IR channels separately, so only in mono mode. The resolution is 640x480 pixel. I grab and publish the images with the openni2-launch launchfile.

issue_title: To configure maximum speed at runtime
issue_contents: I think it is useful to configure the maximum speed of the robot at runtime. It would be helpful for some tasks in which the robot must slow down in the presence of people, when the robot is loading fragile or unstable objects, to reduce the energy consumption or to reduce the noise, for example.
, we are working in a meta controller. The goal of this component is adapting to some circumstances (low battery, waiting for interacting, silent mode) at runtime using
, mainly. This feature could be useful for, but not limited to, our project.
Right now, max speed is configured at startup in the
parameters, and read by the controller (DWB Controller right now). We could use Parameter Events to receive changes in the speed params.
Alternative options could be including in FollowPath action, a field like
I could work on this issue, but I would like to know if you find it interesting for navigation2, and what is the best implementation option.

issue_contents: I am trying to simulate the Franka Panda robot used in Moveit tutorials in Gazebo and move it with the example codes from the tutorials. I think this is going to be a missing part for most of beginners of Moveit. The Setup Assistant seems to be a promising tool based on
But from what I see from trying it, the new tabs in the SA 2.0 are far away from being ready.
Thanks for reporting an issue. We will have a look asap. If you can think of a fix, please consider providing it as a pull request.
2. The fixed virtual joint for mounting the robot to the ground is not working. The robot fails to the ground if you unpause Gazebo.
Just an obervation/comment: MoveIt's fixed joint is
joint. It will not attach your robot to Gazebo's world frame fi.
So your robot falling has a different cause.
is for adding this fixed virtual joint.
I assume when the SA insert elements into the URDF for Gazebo, it should insert a fixed joint to mount the robot to the ground.
Just to leave one thought here. Rather than trying to automatically create URDF files for any industrial robot to be working in Gazebo, integrating with the
projects seems to be more realistic. For example the
seems to be already working. Annoyingly, the UR5 does not have a gripper...
is for adding this fixed virtual joint.
Yes, but that is a MoveIt feature. It does not influence what gets loaded by Gazebo (or any other consumer of the URDF/xacro, for that matter).
I assume when the SA insert elements into the URDF for Gazebo, it should insert a fixed joint to mount the robot to the ground.
I don't believe that happens, but in any case, the "fixed" joint added in step 3 of the tutorial you link is not a
I realized I have not deleted the URDF generated the by the SA.
I don't believe that happens, but in any case, the "fixed" joint added in step 3 of the tutorial you link is not a fixed joint in the urdf.
That does not happen. There is no fixed joint between the world and the base of the robot int the urdf.
The elements inserted into the URDF for Gazebo are wrong. They are inertia matrices of boxes. They should be cylinder inertia matrices. You can see this by turning on the view of inertia in Gazebo.
While working on this we decided to make simulating in gazebo easier, trying to detect the inertia of a shape from an
file seemed a little over killing, so we followed the suggestion in the
The transmissions that are necessary for Gazebo to simulate hardware are missing. I am curious about how this was made working without the transmissions?
They are put at the bottom of the simulation screen after you generate the
Thanks! I see the transmissions when using the SA from the latest source of moveit. I guess the missing transmissions issues was in the deb package version of for ROS kinetic and ubuntu 16.04.

issue_title: Licensing Issues
issue_contents: All of the packages in this repo are currently licensed under BSD 3-clause. However, some developers require their contributions to be under Apache 2.0 to be allowed to contribute during regular work hours. Projects licensed under Apache 2.0 can contain code licensed under BSD but we need to figure out how to handle license notification and licensing of contributions going forward.
probably have experience with this. Hopefully they can offer some guidance.
("some developers" are me, if that wasn't totally clear, so we don't need to keep this too abstract)
Properly changing the license to Apache from BSD is a huge pain though, since we have to seek permission from all past contributors, or at least that's my understanding.

Maybe we can dual license it. In that case I don't know what incoming contributions would be under (both or just one? who chooses?). Though changing to a dual license may also require contacting all former contributors.
do you have input on this?
I'm not an expert on BSD <> Apache2.0 (and this question has come up a few times, I should talk to our lawyers), but off hand does anyone know if I can do
I'm sure I can get permissions to contribute with BSD, but it is a pain. Apache-2.0 I (and probably most companies) can just do it off hand without having to fill out paperwork.
The easiest and least confusing path from the point of view of maintaining and consuming the code is to contribute changes under the same license that was originally used (in this case, BSD-3).
If that's not possible, and we want the changes (and, as
said, we don't want to try to collect permission from all previous contributors to change the original license), then we're adding an additional license to the code. That's not the end of the world.
Here's how I would approach it:
contents_details_more: new changes are being offered under a different, but compatible license (in this case, Apache-2);
accepting those changes will make the code mixed-license, and the maintainer(s) of the repo need to be OK with that change;

in each source file where differently licensed changes are introduced, the license header for the additional license (Apache-2) should be added, probably appended directly after the original license header (BSD-3); and
in each package where such changes are made, the
should be modified to list both licenses in the

issue_title: how to handle tcp collision avoidance
issue_contents: i want to consult  if there are some efficient ways to solve the collision produced by tcps on moveit.

hi, i am developing motion planning module for surgical robot on ur5, and there are several TCPs(tool-center-point) for instance,calibration board,medical operation tools.  when i let the robot move to some target places and postures, it may probably collide with robot links, and i have to manually add waypoints to avoidance this collision, it is time consuming and definitely not practical in the real circumstance. it i do not know whether moveit! has the related part or not on tcp collision avoidance, if it has and how to solve .Ultimately i do not know whether there are some good examples or paper for me to refer to , thank you very much.
Tell us how to reproduce this issue. Attempt to provide a working demo, perhaps using Docker.
to copy-paste the console output or segfault backtrace using gdb.
Thanks for reporting an issue. We will have a look asap. If you can think of a fix, please consider providing it as a pull request.
Please direct such usage questions to

I don't get your question yet, because you confuse TCP with tools: A tool is a physical object mounted at the end-effector of your arm, e.g. calibration board or medical operation tools. The TCP simply defines a virtual coordinate frame, usually at the tip of such tools, which is typically used as the reference frame for inverse kinematics.

Real physical tools should have a collision model in the urdf description of the robot and thus should be considered for collision checking. TCP are, well, virtual, and thus are not considered for collision checking.
sorry, i will ask question to

in the future. maybe i misunderstand the concept of tcp, let us forget tcp just physical tools collision avoidance i actually referred to . you mean the method to settle Real physical tools collision problem is to define its collision model in urdf file, and when planning, moveit will togetherly with other links  consider its collision avoidance? i am newer to it, and slowly to know the details about planning,thank you!
Yes, if there is a collision model for your tool in the urdf, MoveIt will consider it during planning.
thank you very much,you close this issue now.

issue_title: Explorer unable to find path to goal during exploration on robot.
issue_contents: I am in process of putting navigation_2d on robot.
Robot fails during exploration and it keep bumping into obstacles.  Following console prints are received after some time.
[ INFO] [1482263403.132863249]:  Exploration target has been set
[ INFO] [1482263403.132882130]: Map-Value of goal point is 0, lethal threshold is 19.
[ERROR] [1482263403.134084333]: No way between robot and goal!
[ WARN] [1482264165.978509031]: Laser reading 0.003000 not between range_min 0.010000 and range_max 20.000000!
The launch files are as follows:
#set if you want the voxel map published
#set to true if you want to initialize the costmap from a static map
#begin - COMMENT these lines if you set static_map to true
#end - COMMENT these lines if you set static_map to true
observation_persistence: 0.0, marking: true, clearing: true, max_obstacle_height: 1.0, min_obstacle_height: 0.08}

Have you checked if the map that has been build so far is okay? I would always suggest to test map building and navigation separately before going into autonomous exploration. So first make sure that a good map is build when the robot is remote controlled. Then test if navigation is working by setting a goal manually in RVIZ. If both is working, continue with the exploration.
The warning with the laser ranges is probably caused by your laser driver. The
includes min and max range, which seems to be incorrect in your case. But I doubt that this is causing your problems.
Map appear correct on visual inspection. Although I have few doubts.
Any suggestions on improvement of results will be welcome.
This is the expected behaviour in a single robot scenario. The offset frame is relevant in a multi-robot scenario, where the robots have different starting points in the map.

This can be an issue if your wheel slip is too large, so that the scan matching algorithm (which has like all ICP variants a limited convergence radius) cannot compensate for it. If this is really the problem, I would suggest to reduce minimumTravelHeading and minimumTravelDistance. Maybe it's also possible to reduce wheel slip by driving slower?

I am still unable to understand how continuous drift of odom and offset frame is expected in single robot scenario. I expected odom frame to be fixed with map frame. Since I am setting odometry_offset frame to be same as odom frame, they should remain identicle as well. But with time both frame become different.
. I am attaching the launch file I used to run nav2d_karto as well (
The following parameters were used for karto:
is it possible to just nav2d_exploration with move_base, without nav2d_navigator.
Also do nav2d_karo publishes transform map to base_link? I can see pose being published, but not sure about tf part.

Odom and offset will always stay identical in a single robot case. But odom and map will be different, because the odometry will drift over time, so the localization has to compensate for this. Only if you had a perfect odometry with no drift, map and odom would be identical. So the transformation from map to odom shows, how much error has been accumulated by the odometry, (Assuming that the localization is correct of course.)
The exploration-strategies are plug-ins for the navigator, so they cannot be used without it. As explained above, the transformation from map to base_link is available in tf via the following chain:
But this is all handled internally by tf, you can just query tf for the map -> base_link transformation and it will return the correct matrices.

I used your bag-file to build a map, which looks mostly okay. In your yaml you mixed the ros.yaml and the mapper.yaml, which you can't. The frame-names and topic-names have to be on top level, not in the mapper namespace. Please check the examples from nav2d_tutorials.

After a minute or so your robot starts a 360° turn in the large room, which is not reflected in the odometry at all. (You can verify this by replaying the bag-file without the mapper and visualizing it with RViz.) This of course breaks the map completely.
Thank you for explaining the concepts.

Yes, I understood about relation between odom and map. I wrongly typed stating that I hoped odom and map to be same. I actually intended to say that odom and offset should be same for single robot experiments but in some experiments where odom error occurs, I observe sudden drift between odom and offset frame.
Thanks for pointing out mistake in parameter description in yaml file.
I have moved all the frame to ros.yaml as mentioned in tutorial1.launch file. But now I can not keep offset frame and odom frame to error as a TF_SELF_TRASFORM error was reported. Currently

Yes, I also get similar output for first 104 sec of data from bag. After that mapper start consuming a lot of cpu because of which it is not able to register data [ rviz stopped display of odometry tract and laser readings].

I am hoping that loop closure detection will detect failure in odometry and correct the map. I now understand that odometry should be good enough for mapper to work satisfactorily. But I believe mapper should be made robust with the inputs from loop closure detection and optimization in case of odom failures. In attached rosbag, I have teleoperated robot to move in loops in same room. I am expecting algorithm to pick the place as same area and correct in case of odometry drifts. Should I introduced some code to handle such failure cases?

I have also observed that at some places odometry is not captured. And, I observe slippage at places of decline ramps between the rooms. This kind of surface I can not avoid for the robot. I hope to correct these some how. How have you handled such errors [movements not reported by the odometry] in your experiments?
I was able to observe tf between map and base_link using tf_echo binary from tf package.
That was a misunderstanding: I mean that the transformation from offset to odom will always be an Identity in the single robot case. The frame names have to be different in every case!

Loop closing is implemented already within OpenKarto and will trigger automatically if detected. You can visualize the vertices and edges topics in RViz to see when loop closures happen. It can compensate drift that has accumulated over a long time, but it cannot compensate for plain wrong odometry. And if your odometry reports that the robot stands still while it actually turns 360°, this is as far off as it can be.
