issue_title: Indigo release and other questions from industry
issue_contents: My name is XXX, and I'm a lecturer with YYYYYYYY where I'm familiar with KUKA robots. I have recently taken up consulting with with a local company who have a Denso VS-6577GM and RC7 controller.

I understand that the current state of the denso packages in ROS does not support the above. However, it would be to my company's benefit to be able to control this robot without having to use Wingcap III or pacscript, and so I would like to explore the possibility of implementing this support. However, as I'm not familiar with Denso (beyond the pacscript capabilities which I have just learnt up over the past few weeks) and ROS, I'd like to ask the following questions from the both of you.
Thank you, and I apologise for the imposition on your time.

1 The current release of ROS is indigo, and in my distribution (Arch Linux) most packages are already moving there. May I assume that the denso packages in current form are not compatible? And if so, are there plans to do that (git doesn't seem to show much activity in that direction)?

Indigo release is not planned yet, but it has to happen at some point. I assume this will be in early 2015 when we'll hope to see the full maturity of ROS Indigo (it may already have been mature, but we prefer to following "industry" standard to wait for certain period before moving on to a new platform).
2 Some closed issues reference splitting main.cpp to simplify implementing other controllers, are there plans to do this?
Thank you for pointing that out. As

as well, the core components will be replaced with more common controller packages. This change, however, should not change the way the current user interact with the package and the robot (there will only be addtions of new features that are available through the new controllers though).

3 Depending on the answers to above, of course, but what can I do at this point to advance support for the robot I have? Any documentation you can point me to for b-cap would be appreciated, in particular.
You're always welcomed to open questions on this issue tracker for specific topics. Also patches (called
on github as you know) are appreciated.
If you seek a support with guaranteed response timeframe, TORK provides a professional support. Please contact
Please do not hesitate to reopen the ticket if anything is still unclear.
2 Some closed issues reference splitting main.cpp to simplify implementing other controllers, are there plans to do this?
As far as I understand current implementation correctly, you can load and use any ros controller plugin to denso controller. Please try them.

issue_title: hrpsys_config.pyでrtcにservice0という名前のservice consumerがあると落ちる
issue_contents: hrpsys_config.pyで立ち上げるRTCの中にservice0という名前でregisterConsumerしているものがあると、
createCompsの中などのcomp.service("service0")で落ちてしまいます。
rtm.pyの596行目でエラーが出ていて、findServiceにconsumerの名前を与えると落ちるということのようです。
hrpsys-baseのrtm.pyのfindService()でconsumerかproviderか判別してエラー落ちしないようにするか、
そもそもconsumerはservice0というインスタンス名にしない決まりにするかだと思います。
instance_name  Consumer が要求するサービスのインスタンス名
となっているので、service0というインスタンスのサービスに接続するために、
registerConsumerでservice0を指定するのは自然なことでした。
comp.service("service0")とされたときに、providerのみ見るように変更するのが良いのでしょうか。
rtm.pyも変更が必要になる気がします。
findServiceで、polarityがPROVIDEDのもののみ返すようにしました。
これで動きますが、findServiceでconsumerを取ってくることができなくなります。
hrpsys-baseの話なのでこちらに移します。

issue_title: Validate sampling rate of IMU sensor
issue_contents: The sampling rate for the IMU unit is currently at 20 Hz, which may be a little low. It would be nice to see if it could be increased to 100 Hz without much performance impact on the Beaglebone Black. However, this should only be done if we estimate that we are currently losing too much information at 20 Hz, specially for angular velocity and linear acceleration:
Note: the gyroscope sensor operates natively at 800 Hz, and the accelerometer at 1600 HZ.
Maximum rate for the imu capture seems to be around 22Hz. Will continue to investigate if this is a performance issue that we can fix.
With new higher bitrate for i2c, and by using FIFO BYPASS mode for the devices, 130+Hz imu data can be obtained.
However, FIFO BYPASS causes issues with the magnetometer. Also, having a sampling frequency over 20Hz seems to have too much of an impact on performance, especially during recording.
I just found linux drivers for the gyroscope (l3gd20), and accelerometer + magnetometer (lsm303):
Those may allow for better sampling rate than the current implementation. Like for the barometer (bmp180), I was able to compile the drivers. They remain to be tested on the robot.
for all the necessary Linux drivers to install:
It seems that the LSM303D and L3GD20 sensors report data as HAL events:
It seems that the data is published as EV_ABS events:

Right now, the captureBMP node for the barometer, is slower than its accel/gyro counter-part. I suspect this is due to the file reading which can be quite time consuming. I will continue to investigate to speed up the node. Once it reaches an acceptable speed, we could switch LMS303D and L3GD20 to this as well.

I think it is also possible that the delay comes from the overloaded I2C bus. All devices (RTC, accelerometer, gyroscope, magnetometer) are currently sharing that single bus. Running the barometer node alone should show if this is the case or not.
captureBMP was using too expensive read operators on the files. Now it's running well and can go 45Hz+ if we desire.
We should get higher rates, up to 128Hz.

issue_title: Validate the choice of the sampling rate for all sensors
issue_contents: Perform an integrated test on the robot to see how fast can we sample the sensors (e.g. IMU, Create) without saturating the CPU on the Beaglebone Black.
For instance, this is a 'top' output using current configuration during recording:

We may think of creating custom batch messages (similar to audio) for storing more than one sample for the IMU sensor, given that they are sample frequently (e.g. 100 Hz) and sending a single message through a publisher is consuming on the Beaglebone Black. We can still publish the single-sample message once in a while (e.g. 10 Hz), so that the orientation can still be calculated. The madgwick filter also takes significant resources, so it could be applied offline on the rosbag. The batch messages could also be split into individual standard messages during that offline processing.
for batched messages, which solves the high CPU load issues when recording on the robot. Now what remains to be done:
Added unbatching to convert_rosbag.py in commit
for offline rosbag processing with the IMU madgwick filter. More options (e.g. like publishing /tf) should be added soon.
for offline rosbag processing with the odometry estimator. Also added tf publishing support for this script and for the IMU madgwick filter.
I could not test offline odometry since I dont have rosbag recordings new enough to have the topic /irobot_create/joints exposing JointState messages.
for modification of the convert_rosbag.py script, to fix some issues in the unbatched messages.

Here are the latest stats on my last test run. We see that Baro seems to be limited to around 48hz and has a drop rate of 0.20% (ive been seeing this same % for a while now). And Gyro and mag seem limited to 92hz in batch mode (note that they have a 0% dropped rate though) . Aside from that, everything looks consistent.

Here are the stats for when we initiate recording on the robot and control via laptop (with video streaming of one camera to the laptop). This way the cpu isnt saturated (~5% idle). /Imu/Temp seems to have a high drop rate at first, but since it has very few messages,  packets losses  when recording starts has a high impact.
laptop: [nothing]                       roomba : fresh reboot, no joystick node

Note: An odd behaviour ive noticed is that sometimes si% will go very high while us% and sy% go low. The id% tends to be the most reliable to use. Although if we wanted to be more rigorous, we would sample usage over periods of time.
The table and statistics above reported by
confirm that everything runs smoothly, and that we squeeze out the the performance that the Beaglebone Black can offer us.

issue_title: Performance analysis
issue_contents: Investigate if all ressources are used correctly and that there are no flagrant bottlenecks that could impede our tasks.

So far, notice that CPU usage skyrockets to 100% when I start rosbag recording. I have 2 possible explanations: 1 - Rosbag record takes a lot of processing power in all cases and my only recourse is to reduce the number of topics. 2 -  I'm making an error in my subprocess creation and deletion for recording and its causing performance issues (i could use valgrind to investigate this).
Aside from recording, i didn't see anything odd in the performance stats.
Note that recording a rosbag is particularly CPU-consuming when compression is activated. We should make sure that no compression is enabled.
The rosbag recording can be tuned a little with a few parameters on this line:
Try with these additional options, and if this doesn't help, then we can start thinking about filtering some unneeded topics.
Validated and fine with the above modifications.
contents_details_more: Reduce the amount of RAM (in MB) for buffering with --buffsize=128,   and possibly even to 64MB.

issue_title: Change getExtraBits() to uint8_t
issue_contents: The radio and firmware expects the
flags of primitives to be encoded in a single
. In the new AI, this was changed to an array of booleans in the hope that it would be futureproof.

Unfortunately this array is time-consuming and confusing to construct, and the endianess of its contents presents an ambiguity. In addition, all current primitives either do not use this array entirely, or expect it to be either 0 or 1.
The other alternative would be to stick to the status quo.
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.
Sorry for not seeing this sooner.
I'm pretty against this. I think it's putting too much onus on the Primitive class, making it less backend agnostic, and loses semantic meaning. When we implement the radio visitor as part of
, I believe that should have the responsibility of packing the extra bits into a number.
I'm having a difficult time seeing how would this be different except that it's a bit less clear to the programmers. Perhaps this is a non-issue?

The main problem here is that it's trickier to use, easier to make mistakes, and harder to debug. Phrasing this the other way, what's the argument for changing this function instead of putting it in the "radio visitor" class? It seems like this would be less work (one function vs changing all "get Extra Bits" functions in primitives) and semantically more appropriate.
I can't say that it's trickier to use. We could typedef the uint8_t to
as these are used exclusively for primitives. Then the flags would be assigned by bitwise OR-ing with predefined constants.

I agree that the a visitor to the primitive classes is less work. However that seems like a separate issue. If I understood correctly, your suggestion involves the inter-class interaction, specifically the
From my understanding, the objective of this task is to mostly remove the ambiguity from a variable-sized array.
If the only concern was removing the ambiguity from a variable-sized array, one option would be an
with a predefined size of 8. This is kind of a compromise between something of a fixed size that should be easily translatable to a
, but an "easier" structure to work with than a raw
with bit-shifting (at lease on the side of the

As far as I can see, the ambiguity is with the "endianess of the contents" of the array. I'm confused by this though. The array has no endianess, it's an array. The endianess should be decided by whatever is packing the bytes. Another issue pointed out is that the array is "time consuming" to construct. I'm not sure if this refers to computational time or programmer time, but I don't believe that either of those are a problem.
- are you trying to say that bitwise Or-ing by constants is as easy or easy then using an array? If so, I strongly disagree, that seems more error prone and harder to debug.
Also, the radio visitor will exist either way, my point was about where the responsibility of converting a list of flags to a number should lie (I believe it should be in the radio visitor)
I will try to make what I mean more clearer with an example: consider three arbitrary flags and two arbitrary primitives wants to use the extra bits.
Primitive 1 wants to use flag A and flag B. Primitive 2 wants to use flag B and flag C.
We insert the flag state one at a time for each primitive using a loop. The resulting arrays for both primitive extra bits arrays are:

Notice that there is no way to tell which index corresponds to which flag. Also note that because these arrays would have to be converted to an sequence of bits, it's unclear to see if an array like [true, true, false] would be translated to 110 or 011.
So to assign the extra bits, we just need to bitwise the desired flags together. For primitive 1, it would be something like
and for primitive 2 it would be
. The resulting uint for both are:
Notice the "endianess" are defined by the flag constants and no more conversion required. Use bitwise AND to access the state of flags.
As for the radio visitor responsibility, I don't disagree. But that's not in the code right now and we can do that when the time comes.
I do like the explicitness and readability of which flags are being set in this example.
However in your example it seems like you are assuming (correct me if I'm wrong) that different Primitives will use the same flags / flags are applicable to all Primitives. This is not the case.
indicates different things for different Primitives. This means each
class would likely need to define their own flags, not that this is necessarily a problem.
@henrymliu can you clarify exactly what else is in these 8 bits in terms of the radio protocol? I know the reason for restricting to a

is because that's what the radio protocol uses, and we're not messing with that (which is totally reasonable). IIRC there are "generic" bits that enable autokick, enable chipping, and choose between 8 dribbler speeds that apply to all Primitives, but I'm not sure if they fall under the "extra bits" we're referring to here.
What if we left everything to do with encoding Primitives into radio packets to the

classes wouldn't need to worry about endianness or ordering, just the visitor code that translates them to radio packets could use the getter functions to construct the packet. However, removing the generic
functions means we can't use the generic
type to send Primitives over ROS topics.
Just to make sure we're on the same page:

I'm not sure what you mean in your "using arrays" section?  What would you be looping over and where would this loop be? You're absolutely right that it's unclear what the array should be serialized to. This is entirely correct, as the responsibility of interpreting what the correct serialization and de-serialization of the extra bits should be is the responsibility of the radio serialization/de-serialization.

the 8 bits are primitive-dependent and are up to the firmware implementation of each primitive to interpret its contents; there are no generic bits (I think the stuff you may be referring to is encoded separately, outside of the extra bits). The MRFBackend does not care about its contents.

I do not see how the current array is any easier to use for the programmer, it has made it more difficult for me to explain how to format it for new members. Primitives like Shoot use only one bit, as the entire flag is either 0 or 1. In an array form it is now {false, false, false, ..., true}, which IMO is not nice nor intuitive. A simple 0 and 1 clearly communicates "I don't want to chip" or "I want to chip".

When I say "endianness" i meant how it gets interpreted by the programmer when converting this array for use over radio (right to left vs left to right). Since I started writing this comment I see you have already acknowledged this.
has summarized the flag usage very well

how does one immediately know which index of the array corresponds to what desired flag? If a primitive were to ever use multiple bits for flags, it would be much easier and readable to bitwise-OR flags together. I also do not see how it is easier to debug the contents of the array compared to a single int, especially if the exact bit layout of both is known, and the flags are defined constants.

Ok, after some discussion with Mathew, since we should be using visitors to serialize theses primitives (either for a ROS message or radio message), I'm going to implement a visitor to serialize them to ROS messages. This visitor will just use getters on each primitive class, and so I'll also remove

. I believe this will keep the primitives cleaner and alleviate all this confusion. This will also make sure that the different types of serialization (ROS, Radio) are independent, so we will be able to change one without affecting the other.
Okay, I think I have some gaps in knowledge on what you two are planning. We can discuss on Saturday.
contents_details_more: the position of a flag in the array has no inherent meaning (other then what is defined in the

javadoc comment for the primitive in question). So the flag at index 1 for a given primitive could be totally different then the flag at index 1 for another primitive, we do not have a universal set of flags that all primitives return (ie. MovePrimitive might have two flags, PivotPrimitive might have 1 flag, and none of those flags need be the same)

issue_title: Implement Class/Node To Find Good Passes
issue_contents: Implement Class/Node To Find Good Passes

We should implement a new ROS node that allows us to generate good passes for the robots to perform. The reasoning behind putting this in a separate node is that this will likely be a costly operation, and so we would like it to be performed in parallel to normal AI operation (in the previous codebase it was on it's own thread). The pass should be computed using gradient descent (implemented in
) and also by pruning poor passes and generating new ones after some number of iterations of gradient descent.
After some initial work, this will instead be a multi-threaded class that will generate passes in the background, and return the best one found so far on request.
contents_details_more: A "World" ROS message representing the current state of the world
A "Point" ROS message representing the point that the pass should start at
The point that the pass starts from
The point that the pass ends from
The time that the pass should happen at
Unit tests are implemented for any classes
ROSTests are implemented to test to the overall node functionality

issue_title: Define interface for path planner and create placeholder path planner
issue_contents: Define interface for path planner and create placeholder path planner,
The path planner should consume a list of Obstacle (

), a function that returns how much we violate boundaries, a start point, and a destination point. It should return a list of Points that form a path to the destination if one is found, and std::nullopt otherwise.
Create a placeholder path planner that just returns the start and end points.

issue_title: Make libusb wait on file descriptors instead of spinning in a tight loop
issue_contents: The current libusb implementation runs in a tight loop, consuming 100% of CPU and turning computers into space heaters.
The previous implementation used GTK (ugh) to wait on file descriptors, which was a lot more efficient and the preferred way according to the libusb docs.
Change the current impl to wait on FileDescriptors, preferably avoiding GTK though
contents_details_more: Test to make sure radio communication still works

issue_title: Implement path smoothing for navigator paths
issue_contents: Create a function that consumes a list of
that forms a jagged path, and return a smoother path.
Right now, A* will return a jagged list of points due to the fact that we are using a grid graph to find a path. Create a
namespace and create a function that will remove as many points from the path as possible without intersecting any obstacles.
contents_details_more: Create a function that will smooth a path

issue_title: Add Flags to Move Intent
issue_contents: Old AI had special move actions, such as staying on side of the field. This feature needs to be added to new AI.
Add these features as flags to move intents, intending them to be consumed by the navigator or be passed to the primitive level.
We could make specific actions to describe the function of each flag, but unifying the actions into one move intent with flags allows more code reuse.
Would it be useful to add this to the Intent base class, not just MoveIntent?

Hmmm not sure. Traditionally, the flags were only really for the MoveIntent since it was the only one that incorporated navigation. ATM I can't think of a use for the flags in other intents, so for now it's probably easiest to just add them to the MoveIntent. It should be easy to make generic in the future if we need it.
Currently I'm porting over MoveFlags from the old AI; if we ever want other flags for the other intents in the future I should consider that in the design.
Maybe if it's so trivial to port we might as well do it in the first place?

issue_title: Default catkin build ~20x slower than building Release mode
issue_contents: , hector_mapping recently started consuming much more CPU than before. I did some testing using the "catkin" branch today. Compiling as normal using catkin_make, scanmatching times look like this (first number is total callback time including waiting for tf, second one is pure scanmatching time):
As can be seen,  scanmatching routinely takes ~20ms. I tried compiling hector_mapping with specific setting of Release mode (which I thought shouldn´t make a difference):
The runtimes then look like this:
This is about 20x faster than when not building Release explicitly and in the performance ballpark that is expected (and that was the norm using rosbuild).
It thus looks like the compile options used (or the use of catkin within hector_slam) is somehow wrong.

Ok, it looks like hector_slam installed from .debs is using proper compile flags, so this is a problem that might appear when compiling from source (and users have to make sure their catkin workspace is properly configured).

question on ROS Answers. It seems that we managed to not setup our workspace correctly at Team Hector, as I noted ~100% CPU consumption by hector_mapping also on real robots (but will follow up on a internal issue tracker).

Closing this as cause identified. As noted in above posts, one has to take care to specify the proper build type when building catkin packages from source. This is applies to all catkin packages and not just those of hector_slam, however.

CPU consumption drops to about 8% on average and the map looks as expected.

issue_title: RobotTeq motor controller current trip
issue_contents: Need to update firmware on controller to trip at 70 amps (currently 60 amps).
I have a feeling the controller will then just push the motors harder, and we’ll trip at 70A.
Subject: [uf-mil/Navigator] RobotTeq motor controller current trip (
Need to update firmware on controller to trip at 70 amps (currently 60 amps).
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

Roger.  I think the current spike is happening when the thrusters are rapidly switching directions.  I'm going to slow the ramping speed in the firmware.  This will increase the time it takes to switch directions but reduce the current spikes.
Jason is confident that his controller is not the problem.  His integral term prevents rapid reversal of directions.  I'm still looking into the firmware.
Gave new .hex file to Matt for implementation.  Implements a 25% reduction in acceleration and deceleration.  Hoping this will reduce current spikes.
We're holding off on implementing new .hex file.  Jason wants to keep the ramping rates the same for now.  Still not sure why the motor controllers needed to be reset...
Still not sure why the motors need to be reset.  Work around, detect when the motors stop responding, reset motorcontrollers with Daniel's kill board.
Any progress on this? We should start closing issues if they've been resolved.
Hasn't been resolved but hasnt been observed again whilst testing
We had a thruster drop out this past weekend. There was no feedback coming from any of the thrusters so I couldn't check that.
I'd like to consider this partially solved by switching out batteries mid-day.  Agree?

, The current trips were very rare even without the battery swapping, so I do not think enough testing has been done to verify this. It would be nice to have a way to reset the motor controllers in software, but I do not think it is a high priority objective at the moment.
I think this happened both of our last two test days. I'd say this has gone up as a concern in my mind.
Did it happen early in the day or late?  Testing anything unusual?

The battery voltages were around 24 when it failed. This is going to be problematic if we remove the old kill switch since the new kill switches directly cut off power to the motors and don't restart the motor drivers (the only way we know how to fix them).
took a look when we lost power and he said that there was nothing out of the ordinary with the motor drivers (no error LEDs or obvious problems).

The whole inverter dropped out at least once the last weekend as well, and I think this was the cause of most of our network issues in the past. We had a powered USB hub (with the INS and all four FTDI USB motor cables plugged into it) and the POE plugged into the inverter and when network came back up, odom dropped and the motors were unresponsive. After I shuffled USB devices around and restarted the computer things worked again.

I think we should try to remove things from the inverter as much as possible since it seems to drop out. Since most of the devices take AC from the inverter and convert it to DC with a wall wart, could we skip the AC conversion and power it directly from one of the power busses we have onboard? I think it's definitely worth putting some effort into since network loss would be devistating during a practice round and embarrassing if we had to row the boat back to shore.
Roger.  POE takes a weird voltage so it won't be easy to replaced the hardware.  Working with Matt G.  What happened to switching out the batteries halfway through testing?

I spoke to Daniel Dugger about this on the last test day. Both the PoE and switch could be replaced with the same switch that was bought for shore operations. It would also be fairly easy to get a hold of a second PCI USB bus so that the need for a powered hub could be eliminated. This would allow us to remove the inverter all together and make room to properly mount his kill board to the chassis. This not only cleans up the wiring and makes the system more robust, but eliminates the unnecessary power consumption of the inverter.
We hadn't been able to fully charge the replacement set if I remember correctly. So the whole day we operated in the low zone.
The solution I detailed above has been implemented with some minor alterations. We are free from the tyranny of the inverter!
issue_code:
The thruster mapper hard-limits its outputs. They never exceed the safe maximum.

Both controllers I have run are continuous. They are substantially smoother in what they demand than any human could request with the xbox-controller.

The xbox-controller maps full analog-stick tilt to maximum thrust. That means when you are driving it around, you are slamming the thrusters with max-thrust requests. (This is not a problem since the maximum is limited to something safe, but the autonomous controllers are always kinder than this).

I watch the desired wrench on the screen at all time- it doesn't oscillate rapidly because the controller is PD + an integral. The PD term is linear in the state (which changes slowly with respect to thruster speeds) and an integral which is necessarily smooth. There are no sliding-mode or high frequency terms in any controller I have ever run on the boat.

These controllers both have had substantial test with no problems. In fact, MRAC has been running since day 1, and CL has about 2 hours of straight run time at this point."

issue_title: rtmlaunch.pyでimportエラーが発生する
issue_contents: rtmros_commonをsourceから入れてcatkin buildすると，
rtmlaunchで下記のようなエラーが発生します．
ここまでのcommitではrtmlaunchが起動できています．
commitというよりmanifest.xmlがあるかないかで変わるようです．
commitというよりmanifest.xmlがあるかないかで変わるようです．
こちらの想定としては、実質不要なファイルなのであっても動いてくれるはず
manifest.xmlがあるとrtmlaunchが正常に起動しますが，
manifest.xmlがないと以下のエラーで起動できないです．
pathかなにかが良くないでしょうか．
rtmros_common/openrtm_tools以下にmanifest.xmlがある場合，起動できる．
ない場合，起動できないです．
pythonpathを作るときにこれを見に行くから重要情報であはる．
On Thu, Apr 21, 2016 at 8:05 PM, iory
rtmros_common/openrtm_tools以下にmanifest.xmlがある場合，起動できる．
ない場合，起動できないです．
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
pythonpathを作るときにこれを見に行くから重要情報であはる．
On Thu, Apr 21, 2016 at 8:05 PM, iory
rtmros_common/openrtm_tools以下にmanifest.xmlがある場合，起動できる．
ない場合，起動できないです．
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
rtmros_commonだけのworkspaceをつくるとどうなるかな
この状態でもmanifest.xmlを持ってくると,
rtmlaunch openrtm_tools test-rtmlaunch.testは起動します．
On Thu, Apr 21, 2016 at 9:11 PM, iory
この状態でもmanifest.xmlを持ってくると,
rtmlaunch openrtm_tools test-rtmlaunch.testは起動します．
You are receiving this because you commented.
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
これでrtmlaunchうごかないかな
動くようになりました．
debのpackageになにかしらしてしまっていたということでしょうか
rosではいるopenrtm-pythonはros-indigo-openrtm-python，一方JVRCかなにかのときにopenrtm-pythonが松阪さんのppaから入るようになっている．
で問題はこの２つのバージョンが微妙に違うので，動かないことになっているきがする．
みたいなので差分を調べたい．あと，どこかのMLで一回この話題出ている気がするので検索してみる．
たしかに昨日jvrc用のpackageをいれていました．
もう少し調べてみます．
これですか？ タイトルとはちょっと違うけど中身は、OpenRTMのdebの話になっていっていたような。
ありがとうございます．そのissueでも言及されていますね．
結局どうするのがいいでしょうか．
choreonoidを入れるときにopenrtm-aist-pythonを入れてしまうと，
hrpsysを立ち上げる時に問題となるかもしれないのですが
ROSが走ってるマシンではchoreonoid使わない、が現実的な気がしますが、それ置いておいて
manifestを入れると動くのは不思議
落ちる直前あたりでprint(sys.path)辺りをすると何が違うだろうか
importのところで，そもそもOpenRTM__POAがComponentObserverを持っていないで落ちていて，
普通にprint debugをすると，以下のような変更で(rtmlaunch)
いかが正常に起動した場合です．
それで動くようになりました
そっちのほうがいいですかね．
travisが失敗しているようですが，
と出ているのですが，これはどうすればいいでしょうか？
ときどきあるので，travisをリスタートして下さい．

issue_title: initialization of the first epoch
issue_contents: Thanks for your great work on this package. Currently, the first position of this package is given manually. but if the initial position is not given accurately, it may fail to initialize. how big the error of the initialization is acceptable in this package?
It depends on the number of the particles (
parameter) and covariance of the initial pose (
As another solution, this package has global localization that can be triggered by
Of course, global localization service requires a lot of computation power; it is not reasonable for large maps on the current implementation.
thanks for your kind reply, I find that only several beam is used in the beam model of this package.  why you do not use more beams? this is becasue the ray-casting process is quite time-consuming?
this is becasue the ray-casting process is quite time-consuming?
Yes, especially with the long range LIDAR.
You can try increasing number of beams by
The current implementation is not very optimal and the possibility of optimizing ray-casting in this package is quite large.
sure, do you think the ray-casting in octomap format will be faster?
do you think the ray-casting in octomap format will be faster?
I tried octree in PCL before.
The overhead seems bigger than kd-tree and likelihood computation cost increased a lot.
I haven't tried octomap. It needs complete rewriting of the node, I guess.
Closing as the question looks been resolved. Feel free to reopen, or open a new issue, if you have any other questions on this topic.
issue_quotes: this is becasue the ray-casting process is quite time-consuming?
do you think the ray-casting in octomap format will be faster?

issue_title: Support for providers implementing multiple interfaces
issue_contents: For example the Kobuki driver aka kobuki_node (could) implements multiple interfaces, e.g. DifferentialMobileBase, Gyro, Button, LED etc.
Do we already cover such cases?
You can have each of those capabilities just depend on another capability, say
, which is responsible for starting the

This feature would significantly complicate the internal implementation of the capability server. I would prefer to leave it out for now as there is a way to represent this using another capability interface. This might be a feature worth supporting in the future, but from my perspective it is syntactic sugar, which I would not prioritize over other issues with the system.
I agree with your approach. I'll give more feedback once I get around implementing your previous suggestion.
I implemented an initial set of caps for Kobuki (
So far I didn't run into any show stoppers when following your tb2 example.
I'd like to leave this issue here open for a bit longer until I can implement the full support for the Kobuki base and link upcoming related issues to here.
Just ran into a new issue related to this, which is about remapping.
In the above Kobuki example there are several interfaces, which are actually all implemented by the
, but currently represented by several "fake" providers all depending on the
Shouldn't "fake" providers all be launched (set to be running), when their dependency is launched? That would represent the reality, e.g. starting the

Sorry, I forgot that we decided for now that the providers adhere to the interfaces. I.e. they are responsible for providing the topics specified in the interface - either by default or via roslaunch remappings.

So, adjusting the above statement: For a provider implementing multiple interfaces the current approach would mean the remappings necessary for all implemented interfaces need to be applied right from the start.
However, how will we then cope with semantic interfaces? E.g.
as well as the semantic interfaces
Currently, one solution would be to set up a default remapping from
. Doesn't look like a clean solution to me though.
I just spent this morning digging into options for remapping a running node. The current system doesn't allow for this.
I think the best option for remapping topics is to use the relay topic tool:
I believe this is actually really efficient because it doesn't deserialize the message before passing it along.
However, that only allows us to deal with topics. I can imagine a system for doing the same with parameters, but services, actions, and dynamic parameters seem problematic.
A final option is to add specific support for this in the Kobuki node. We could have a service on it like

which would take topic names to and from and internally would perform the remapping. This could also be applied to services and actions, but still not dynamic parameters. But this doesn't scale very well.

All of these options sound like bad options, but the last one seems most complete. You could even imagine that we setup a library to make providing these services easy and transparent, but that will likely take a bit of time to implement.
I just spent this morning digging into options for remapping a running node. The current system doesn't allow for this.
Sounds to me like this topic should be on the list for ROS 2.0. Are there any plans addressing this?
I think the best option for remapping topics is to use the relay topic tool:
I believe this is actually really efficient because it doesn't deserialize the message before passing it along.
What about bandwidth? Relaying high bandwidth topics, such as point clouds, would put extra load on the system, no? The TB laptops already have a hard time coping with the Kinect data.

A final option is to add specific support for this in the Kobuki node. We could have a service on it like ~remap which would take topic names to and from and internally would perform the remapping. This could also be applied to services and actions, but still not dynamic parameters. But this doesn't scale very well.
I'm not in favour of this custom solution either. Also, this situation will happen more often in the future, I believe, e.g. create node, probably also navigation and moveit.

One option could be to restart the node responsible for the conflicting topics with the correct remappings, whenever new capabilities are started. This might work for now, since we limit ourself to one app at a time. Later it probably would play havoc with the running apps , i.e. each new app would require the running ones to restart, since their capabilities are restarted.

Another option would be using a feature, which we have discarded for now. That is allowing providers and semantic providers to specify their own topics for the interface they implement. E.g. The provider for
instead of remapping at start to
would to the same and the provider for
Positive side effects: This would remove the requirement for remappings done by the capability server and it would be already supported by the app manager.
Sounds to me like this topic should be on the list for ROS 2.0. Are there any plans addressing this?

Yes, a more introspectable and dynamic computation graph is near the top of the list, but this is not likely something that will be implemented in the near term, as it implies changing the entire middleware discovery, negotiation and connection protocol.
What about bandwidth? Relaying high bandwidth topics, such as point clouds, would put extra load on the system, no? The TB laptops already have a hard time coping with the Kinect data.

Certainly, but sending data over the local loop back with TCP is nearly as fast as shared memory (Assuming you also copy into and out of shared memory like you do for read and write buffers on the socket). The real cost you are used to seeing is the serialization/deserialization of these large data structures, which would be skipped in this case.
Either way this is an incomplete solution at best and doesn't address at all nodelets.
One option could be to restart the node responsible for the conflicting topics with the correct remappings, whenever new capabilities are started.

This also doesn't address requests for both the LED capability and the LED1 semantic capability at the same time. In that case you don't want to remap, but really you want to setup something like topic aliases or symbolic links so that the kobuki node can service both subscribers.

Another option would be using a feature, which we have discarded for now. That is allowing providers and semantic providers to specify their own topics for the interface they implement. E.g. The provider for LED specifies /mobile_base/command/led1 for /led instead of remapping at start to /led. The provider for KobukiLED1 would to the same and the provider for KobukiLED2 would specify /mobile_base/command/led2 for /led.

This sounds like a reasonable solution for the app server in the case where the consumers are outside of the rosmaster that the capability is on, i.e. communication is establish through the app server's flipping of topics.

I am willing to go down that route, what would that need to look like? Would this only be for semantic capabilities? I don't suppose all providers would need to provide this mapping, if they naturally fulfill the interface?
in the case where the consumers are outside of the rosmaster that the capability is on, i.e. communication is establish through the app server's flipping of topics.
To me this seems also needed for the case, when using the same rosmaster in order to solve the remapping issue.
I don't suppose all providers would need to provide this mapping, if they naturally fulfill the interface?
Correct. That's why I would make this remapping optional.
Would this only be for semantic capabilities?
No. Should be usable for both normal and semantic capabilities.
I am willing to go down that route, what would that need to look like?
I guess, adding remapping parameters to the provider specification would suffice.
I implemented most parts on the app manager side to support provider remappings. I'll finish that as soon as there is support for them in the capability server.
Ok, I'll probably spend tonight and tomorrow morning on implementing the provider remappings.
issue_code: Support for providers implementing multiple interfaces
Support for nodes providing multiple interfaces

%YAML 1.1
---
name: kobuki_led
spec_version: 1
spec_type: provider
description: "Implements the LED capability for Kobuki's default LED, i.e. LED 1."
implements: kobuki_capabilities/LED
depends_on:
    'kobuki_capabilities/KobukiBringup':
        provider: 'kobuki_capabilities/kobuki_bringup'
remappings:
  topics:
    'led': '/mobile_base/commands/led1'

issue_title: Kuka Kr6r900sixx Joints not found
issue_contents: I tried to use the Kr6r900 in MoveIt. Therefore I created an kr6_moveit_config folder with the moveit_assistant using the xacro_urdf file from /kuka_kr6_support/urdf folder. After navigating to the launch folder within the moveit_config folder I started demo.launch in Terminal.

As result RViz opens with the Robot but if I try to plan a random path it consumes a lot of time and the Solution found is a complicated Path with lots of useless motions. In Terminal I get the following Error for each of the Joints:
It seems like MoveIt is trying to load the Joint from the Kr6r900sixx file but instead of searching for Joint 1 to Joint 6 it uses the names from the UR Package.
At first I had the UR and Kuka files in the same Catkin Workspace. But even after seperating them in two different Workspaces the Error occured.
files that the setup assistant generated?  There should be a list of the joint names in one of them (I believe it's
Thank you for your super fast answer.
This is the config file that has been created. I checked them but they seem to be fine.
As result RViz opens with the Robot but if I try to plan a random path it consumes a lot of time and the Solution found is a complicated Path with lots of useless motions
Make sure you have selected a good planner on the MoveIt planning request setup tab. See
I tried to use the Kr6r900 in MoveIt. Therefore I created an kr6_moveit_config folder with the moveit_assistant using the xacro_urdf file from /kuka_kr6_support/urdf folder.
works for you. That branch contains a KR6 R900 sixx MoveIt configuration with everything setup to use it with ROS-Industrial (or just through the
If you plan on using this with the
package and a real robot, please make sure to replace
with the IP address of your ROS PC that it uses to communicate with the robot, and to read the updated RSI setup instructions in
). Experiences of a KR10 R1100 user at

The MoveIt config is experimental (hence the need for some minor manual patching) and the installation instructions are in the process of being updated. These changes will be merged soon, which will make things go a little smoother.
Feel free to ask questions if something isn't clear.
As to your original problem: I suspect this is something local to your machine / ROS environment setup, rather than an issue with the xacro we have in the
xacro doesn't contain those joints, so it would seem strange for them to show up in a MoveIt configuration based on it.
Even though I could not solve the original Problem you're MoveIt setup works perfectly fine for me.

issue_title: Implement ROS node for gluing VISIBILITY callbacks
issue_contents: Let's assume all browsers already send a readiness signal to their AdhocBrowserPools so pools mark them as ready for showing. There needs to exist an external node that interprets director messages, divides adhoc browsers to logical groups and emits a message after all browsers from a single activity joined.
If this task is testable - include list of commands and expected outputs.
1 - director message gets emitted for 2 browsers:
contents_details_more: Interpret each director message so all adhoc browser activities (there can be many as opposed to previous state where it used to be only
activity) and divide them to groups. For every group keep list of browsers that are waiting for being loaded.
For every group that all browsers have become ready, emit a string with their activity name on
Above signal will be consumed by AdhocBrowserPool and launcher that emitted the scene and was waiting for the readiness signal.
extensions in browsers emit messages on
readiness ROS node publishes a message on

That said, I'd like to understand what about your system has caused this to happen. Could you give us some specs?

What is minimum compute requirement for cartographer package for online behaviour?.

contents_details_more: On your 14.04 system, it seems that your version of Eigen is incorrect. The correct version of Eigen for 14.04 is 3.2.0-8. Perhaps you manually installed a different version?
The required hardware for real-time performance is any relatively modern PC.

Optimizations happen in the background after a fixed number of scans have been added to the map. Multiple optimizations may pile up if they're not fast enough. This should happen rarely on a properly configured system. Since optimizations only occur every n-scans, you can use the /finish_trajectory service to perform a final optimization after all bag data has been consumed.

We need to support this use case:
String name pairs don't have to be unique - the hub server ip/port is enough to guarantee uniqueness.
Absolutely need this - can think of several use cases where it's important.
But...its complicated. Let's hammer forward and get it working end to end first.
I'm going to do this in rocon_gateway....:)
Any other way would just be....too easy?
This is for tracking jobs on the multi-hub
Caught me by surprise this one....it was a really major refuctor! Good chance to clean up the gateway properly though.

Zeroconf constantly getting polled for new hubs as they appear.
Offline subsystem offering a service on the public interface

Build it from multiple rocon_gateways and consume it inside an automated framework elsewhere.

issue_title: Joint feedback - Velocity and Acceleration
issue_contents: It just came to my attention that the Joint Feedback messages have fields for velocity and acceleration.  It would appear that this data gets populated into the velocity/effort fields of [rostopic echo /joint_states].
However, the MotoROS driver doesn't actually populate these fields.  The [validFields] mask is set to 2 for position only.
Is this ok?  Should I be populating the velocity/acc fields?  Is this data useful for anything?
If the controller makes that data available, then yes please, populate it. Same goes for the
As to the usefulness: I would say it's always useful to have as much state information available as possible, even if right now use-cases might not be apparent.
Personally I would however not derive those values (by dx/dt fi).
I can get the feedback-speed and torque for each axis on FS100, DX200, and YRC1000 (not DX100).

However, as best I can tell from looking at MotoROS and the Industrial Core, the joint feedback message isn't designed to accept effort/torque.  Are you suggesting that I overwrite the acceleration field with the torque?  Or that I add a new member to the feedback-message?  If I increase the size of the feedback message, will that break anything in the Industrial Core? (I haven't delved into it in great detail yet)

The ROS side and MotoPlus size message definitions have to match.  We could make that happen, but I'm more worried about sending even more data through the controller.  Does the controller have a max packet size for socket comms?

Probably...  but I expect that the TCP stack on the controller should accommodate the normal MTU for ethernet, which is 1500 bytes (need to test, of course).  If I add a torque field, it would put a SmBodyJointFeedbackEx packet at 692 bytes.
However, as best I can tell from looking at MotoROS and the Industrial Core, the joint feedback message isn't designed to accept effort/torque.
fields as well. It is only available in IRCv2.

Are you suggesting that I overwrite the acceleration field with the torque? Or that I add a new member to the feedback-message? If I increase the size of the feedback message, will that break anything in the Industrial Core? (I haven't delved into it in great detail yet)
Well, we could, but that would mean an update to the ROS side as well. Not sure that is worth it. Might as well do that when/if
I'm more worried about sending even more data through the controller. Does the controller have a max packet size for socket comms?
I'm not too worried about this. The TCP/IP stack on the Motoman controllers is pretty sane (after all, it's vxworks), and MotoPlus applications have (almost) direct access to that.
: would adding the velocity data to the
msgs be something you could implement?
For some things we're starting to look at here it might come in handy to have that data available.
And a question on ROS Answers about this:
aren't missing, I'm pretty sure the OP misremembered).
I haven't actually tested this yet beyond compiling.
Did you remove all pkgs except
For the future; could you please commit such large changes in a separate commit? The additions for the velocity feedback are now burried in a commit that touches 351 files ..
Yeah... I realized that after I committed.  Let me know if you need me to redo this repo.
I've attached a comparison report that shows the files that were actually changed.
It would be really nice if you could push the same changes, but then either not delete the pkgs, or do everything in two commits.
You could also do this in a separate branch on your regular
fork, if that would be more convenient.
I just reverted and re-pushed the changes.
Haven't validated the output (ie: correspondence between commanded and reported velocities), but MotoROS seems to function as it should and I get sane data on the
Is there a rate limit on the velocity feedback that MotoPlus makes available? It appears to lag a bit and seems a bit discretised as well.
I'm not sure. I've never actually used this API before, but I expected it to have the same behavior as the feedback-position API.
I'll need to run some additional tests.

I have run some additional testing and got similar results to yours.  I compared the values to the [Servo Monitor] function on the pendant and they are identical (including the aggregation/discretization).  So, I believe that this result is the best I can obtain using the MotoPlus API for feedback speed.  I will prepare a report and send to HQ in Japan... but this will take a long a time to discuss and potentially improve.
There is one other way to obtain the feedback speed without additional hardware.  I ran a quick test and found that this does provide data with finer granularity. But there are couple drawbacks:

While I'm at it, is this a good time to implement feedback torque?  If there were some kind of version-check message implemented in motoman-driver, I could use it to maintain backward compatibility of the MotoROS portion.

I suspect the delay for the feedback will be greater because the data has to get routed through a few layers in the controller before I can access it in MotoROS. But, given that it's a more accurate representation of the instantaneous speed, maybe this is a moot point.

Delay is undesirable. But discretisation is also undesirable. I can't really decide whether one is worse than the other. In most cases delayed data is unusable, whether it's discretised or not (too old == too old). And for applications where info about velocity is interesting, I believe that delay would always be undesirable.

There are a bunch of protected robot parameters which must be enabled to use this function. Since we just got away from requiring yaskawa-level parameters, I don't want to go back to it. I have an idea of how it could possibly be automated in MotoROS... but that piece could not be published open-source. I would need to put it in a pre-compiled library.
That would not be different from how the 'parameter extraction' works right now, correct?
This would consume a LOT of robot M registers. If someone starts to combine MotoROS with other robot options, it's very possible there could be a resource conflict.
That could definitely be a concern. Personally I think it's nice to have velocity feedback available, but not at all costs.

While I'm at it, is this a good time to implement feedback torque? If there were some kind of version-check message implemented in motoman-driver, I could use it to maintain backward compatibility of the MotoROS portion.
There is no versioning in the protocol unfortunately, so that is not something we can exploit.
does not include effort, only acceleration. If we want to add this, we'd either have to repurpose the acceleration field or introduce a new message (IRCv2 does actually include

Have been a long time lurker here. It would certainly be nice to see information beyond positions on the robot state feedback when one starts thinking about realizing dynamic behaviours (I mean, those that make use of the robot dynamics).

Delay is undesirable. But discretisation is also undesirable. I can't really decide whether one is worse than the other. In most cases delayed data is unusable, whether it's discretised or not (too old == too old). And for applications where info about velocity is interesting, I believe that delay would always be undesirable.

With regard to having to pick between delayed or discretised information, the latter is perhaps preferable imo. As already pointed out, delays are definitely undesirable and require quite some attention from the user to compensate for them before acting on the information. However, with discretised information, there is at least a possibility to perform a naïve linear extrapolation of the current value based on the sampling interval (which would take relatively less time). Of course, such (a) workaround(s) would be with an assumption that the information (velocity in this context) is not drastically changing within one sampling interval.
I have performed testing to compare the MotoPlus API vs the M-Register method to read feedback speed.  It turns out I was wrong about the delay.  The M-Register method is definitely superior.
So, I need to investigate the viability of deploying the M-Register method and automating it inside of the param-extraction library.  (I'm not even sure if this is an "official" controller feature.)
(ignore the sign on the second part of the plot, it's incorrect).
Both the delay as well as the discretisation of the MotoPlus API feedback is clearly visible here.

I have implemented the change to the Param Extraction library to automatically enable all the parameters for high-speed Register Speed Feedback. It turns out that these are all user-level parameters (not protected)... but there's a bunch of them and this method helps to eliminate confusion/error.

At startup, the library will attempt to read the param values.  If they are not set, it will automatically enable them.  This will require a reboot the first time it is done, so I raise an alarm, "8001 [10] Speed FB enabled, reboot now". After that, velocity data will be included with the Joint Feedback messages.

The high-speed register method is only available for DX200 and newer.  So, for DX100 and FS100, I am disabling velocity feedback entirely.  I figure that MotoPlus-API method (above) is pretty useless.  Thoughts?
If this gets merged into the main branch, I plan to add some wiki pages with these details.

Are there any known conflicts or issues if I merge these changes into the main branch and submit a PR? I'm assuming that the existing ROS-I code can handle velocity data being transmitted, even if it's not used by the final application.
I would suggest creating a new branch on your regular
fork. Commit the changes to that fork, and open a PR from that fork against
That way even if a review / testing round takes some more time, you won't be 'blocked', as you can just work in a different branch.
I can't test this - as I only have an FS100 - but perhaps we can find someone with a DX200 or YRC1000 that could take a quick look.
I'll take a look at the ROS side to make sure that the deserialisation results in proper
msgs with the velocity fields populated. I'm assuming it's all ok, as it already worked with what you posted in
, but it's good to check in any case.
I'll ask Erc Marcil to validate on my end.
If you need this feature on the FS100, you could try the API mpSvsGetVelTrqFb. This gets speed and torque feedback at a good rate. (I only recently learned of this API.)
Thanks. That is good to know.
Would you accept a PR adding that to the
Yeah.  I can probably get around to it on Monday.  Or, feel free to submit it sooner.
Joint Velocity feedback was added in
Effort is available on the controller, but due to limitations in the simple message msgs currently used by the driver, cannot be reported back to ROS.
Closing this, as for now this has been addressed/implemented as far as is possible.
We'll revisit adding effort to the state reporting msgs at a later time.
issue_quotes: However, as best I can tell from looking at MotoROS and the Industrial Core, the joint feedback message isn't designed to accept effort/torque.

Are you suggesting that I overwrite the acceleration field with the torque? Or that I add a new member to the feedback-message? If I increase the size of the feedback message, will that break anything in the Industrial Core? (I haven't delved into it in great detail yet)
I'm more worried about sending even more data through the controller. Does the controller have a max packet size for socket comms?

I suspect the delay for the feedback will be greater because the data has to get routed through a few layers in the controller before I can access it in MotoROS. But, given that it's a more accurate representation of the instantaneous speed, maybe this is a moot point.

There are a bunch of protected robot parameters which must be enabled to use this function. Since we just got away from requiring yaskawa-level parameters, I don't want to go back to it. I have an idea of how it could possibly be automated in MotoROS... but that piece could not be published open-source. I would need to put it in a pre-compiled library.
This would consume a LOT of robot M registers. If someone starts to combine MotoROS with other robot options, it's very possible there could be a resource conflict.

While I'm at it, is this a good time to implement feedback torque? If there were some kind of version-check message implemented in motoman-driver, I could use it to maintain backward compatibility of the MotoROS portion.

Delay is undesirable. But discretisation is also undesirable. I can't really decide whether one is worse than the other. In most cases delayed data is unusable, whether it's discretised or not (too old == too old). And for applications where info about velocity is interesting, I believe that delay would always be undesirable.

Yeah. Tell me about it. I kind of gave up last month on being surgical and just merged everything. That lead to merging something that shouldn't have been merged. I would not have known it wasn't supposed to be merged, though. I think we need the authors, or at least someone familiar with the change to make the call on whether it should be backported. issue_title: Re-think how AvoidAreas should work
issue_contents: Now that we better understand our use cases for AvoidAreas, how we use them, and how we (think) we want to control them we should rethink the idea in general. They work well and the idea of discrete areas to avoid on the field makes sense, but how they were set and communicated between the strategy and the navigator got too complicated.
We should figure out how we want to solve this. New datastructures? New concept entirely?
One suggestion was to replace the AvoidArea enums with classes and inheritance (a class for each discrete type of area).
I scoped out the work in
. Can you review that and let me know if I close this issue?
but otherwise they seem fine. Maybe we should still leave this ticket open until the others are completed in case more work is broken out?
supersedes this so we can close this one.
contents_details_more: class, and concrete implementation of each "type", like area around ball.
function that can be consumed by the navigator generically.
The classes could also be constructed with parameters if Tactics or Actions need more direct control
Make a plan for how to handle AvoidAreas
Rename “AvoidAreas” to instead represent rules & constraints on rules
Remove all “AvoidAreas” that are NOT related to rules
Avoiding robots based on the rules is the responsibility of the navigator, the actions/intnets should have no knowledge of it
MoveIntent will have a flag for touching / not touching the ball, because there is semantic information in the high level about whether to touch the ball or not

No more whitelist/blacklist in the tactic or play. Instead, have a visitor that produces a list of AvoidAreas/RuleConstraints as a function of a tactic and a gamestate ((Tactic,GameState)->std::vector).
In all cases where there is a play whitelisting something on a tactic, we probably just need another tactic (for example, kickoff)
STP manager will getruleconstrainsts and then apply to intent from tactic

which are used to compute the lattice. However, the

which is used by the /command_converter and refers to the state (attitude/velocity) of the vehicle.

can update you on current conventions and his more stable work in 'open-planner'. I think the fix would be relatively simple given accurate information about naming conventions....

and it solved the issue. However I still cannot run the simulation mode. I'm trying to replicate something similar to the case observed in this
. What I do are the following steps:

was not generating any information that would produce a valid

issue_title: [Discussion] Planning Architecture
issue_contents: , we need to create the design overview of planning.
, we can start this by defining inputs/outputs and logics in these 4 layers.
Thanks for his suggestion, for example,
Global planning => on demand service, interface to apriori map and traffic information,
Behaviour planning => open problem, Darpa urban challenge: rule-based, other companies: search-based method, our favorite: robust POMDP
Local planning => some deterministic sampling-based methods (GMT) or form of MPC, pre-recorded path, RRT
I think the Motion Layer in present Autoware architecture (
I created the draft design about these and commented at
volunteered to lead the redesign for this package. I will chime in after his initial draft.
I think the main quality of a good stack or architecture is that it should be easy to extend.
I think this is especially important as Autoware is a very ambitious open source project.
Generally, to achieve a stack that is easy to extend, the following is very helpful:
With respect to this, I think from a conceptual, robotics algorithms level, the standard planning stack of:
Is a good one, as it logically separates planning into distinct algorithm domains, making it easy to reason about planning from an algorithm perspective.

How, within each of the five components, each one is structured is a matter of debate, whether it be more class-based, or node based. I personally favor a more monumental, class-based means of separating concerns.
If we can achieve this, then we would be able to interchange algorithms at each level from various contributors.
The thinking then is that we could have a hierarchy of launch files, e.g.
Where then each particular launch file can e.g. dispatch to many nodes, as in
's design, or a single node, if it is from another contributor who designs it that way.
That said, here is a first proposal for interface messages. Here, I am favoring standard messages where possible:

Just some suggestions and discussion points. I think on the motion/local planning and control level, those proposals are fairly concrete, as the interfaces here a pretty well understood. At the higher behavior and global planning levels, it might be challenging to design a good interface, since the solutions and problem settings become a lot more broad.
, I am late to this conversation so I thought I start with aligning the task.

In my opinion, let's separate the design first into functionality before going into details on the interface types. This means hashing out the role of these modules first and also deciding which ones are processes vs libraries. A process communication with a library does not have to go through ROS which is sometimes very useful. Afterwards the interface details become more apparent.
Here is a first shot at this.

For these process commands from flow the top (mission -> behavior -> motion -> control) with simultaneous increase in information update. Controller runs fastest (100hz, 50hz). Status information is reported upwards. This ensures a single source of 'truth' to allow for consistent decisions.
With this separation, ROS communication is only
handling is crucial across the full hierarchy here, so I highly recommend using namespaces like
Your comment fell a little awkwardly before the short holidays
Regarding what is written, I broadly agree. I was under the false impression that some of these were a given, but it's best to be as clear as possible.
As far as general development practice goes:
I guess my main comments in short are:
RE- global/mission planner - Yes, lane sequence is no the right abstraction, I think waypoints (with some possible semantic meaning) is a good start.
I also agree about keeping things as ROS agnostic as possible and only adding wrappers to tie the modules to ROS at the end.
For scene modeling , it is the piece hard to find examples of, yet is can vastly affect the interfaces in motion planning (e.g. representation of obstacles)
I haven't looked deeply in OMPL, but AFAIK it is mostly geared towards manipulation planning, so I am not sure how much of that interface fits AD.
Example MP interface I had in mind:
The have a factory for registering and initializing motion planners.

I agree with the options. Just want to add one more thing that the full map or a large portion of it is not needed by most of these components. Only routing and lane level reasoning need access to large portions of the map and they mostly use topological information and some geometric info. I think these can be represented in some object build from a map (which could be living in a server/database etc) and the object is updated rarely.

More intermediate components like motion planners, behavior planner and controllers do not really need access to a map but rather just a definition of workspace. These could again be objects build from either the map portion used in routing or a combination. These workspace objects will need to be constructed every time a planning 'call' is to be made so it is important the process if efficient.
For optimization based planners for instance, these workspace object could then represent continuous spaces.
This decouples how localization interacts with maps. The routing and planning modules here then only consume output of a localization module (as some 'State' object, again an interface).

Mainly state of the controller process, as in health and online tracking errors. The idea is to provide a channel for a user to propagate such diagnostics upwards and do something with them if need be or just log for debug purposes.

Took a look, I like their models for spaces, objective functions and all. I think we can borrow a lot from these. What I didn't see (maybe didnt look hard enough) was arc length parameterization type spaces, i.e. Frenet coordinate which are prevalent in AV.

I like the optimization approach very much too. I think we can have some basic interfaces for all of these and have a reference implementation of an optimization based planner from which other users can derive and add more.
Finally,  I think the discussion so far has been very fruitful, how should we go forward now?
I guess for next steps we need to consider what the purpose of this discussion to hash out an architecture was. IMO the point of hashing out an architecture is so that we can establish standards to:
In light of that I guess some kind of document would be best. IMO it should probably have:

I think we should get this tarted right away so that any lingering issues/decisions can be surfaced sooner.
Should we do [development guidelines] on this repo, maybe via a series of Markdown docs or elsewhere?

I think standard practice is that we have a (series?) of markdown documents in the repository wiki (e.g. Developer/Contributor Guidelines etc.). We could also have a section of the readme in the planning section of the repo, e.g.:
If the larger project also takes up some of these guidelines, we could also have the highlights be in some kind of message when a user is trying to open a MR (I don't know if this is possible).
I think we should get this tarted right away so that any lingering issues/decisions can be surfaced sooner.
Sounds like a plan. Did you want to take a first stab at it? If not, I should hopefully have some time to sit down and string some words together within a few days.
I am looking forward to see your design document.
Let me share with you some thoughts:

Planning has very wide range of implementations and standards. so fixing the design on what you prefer or like (for example Optimization based trajectory planner) is not the way to go. you should think more generally.
You should not include vehicle_control/path_following in the planning design, it is different problem.
Planning modules should support simulation, planning based on HD maps, planning based on Occupancy Grid (free space planners).
Design and scientific bases, check paper
check the tutorial and illustration videos on YouTube.
Initially, OpenPlanner design was to separate Global Planning (way_planner) and Local Planning (dp_planner). you can still find the nodes and tested in simulation mode.
Secondly from last year we had discussion with Autoware team to divide dp_planner to several nodes (similar proposal as

There is one library which contains the Planning functions and Logic op_planner. the nodes only concerned with message passing, parameters, synchronization, visualization. (same as suggested) with the addition that I like to separate the visualization in the future.
The only enforcement for others to implement their own sub modules is the nodes interface definition:
issue_code:
3. Local planning
4. Control
# planning.launch.py
global_planner = 'global_planner.launch.py'
behavior_planner = 'behavior_planner.launch.py'
# .. etc..
/motion_planner/ego_lane/param_x
* I think how we handle this might depend on what paradigm is chosen for handling maps

* Mainly I see 2-3 ways of interacting with maps:
  
  1. Shared database (e.g. each relevant node can access/query the same map database)
  2. Decoupled (e.g. only top level node, such as global planner, has access to map, and only relevant info is passed via messages down)
  3. Server (similar to 1, but map is a ROS server, rather than some indeterminate object in shared memory)

* 1 probably wouldn't work out too well in a multi-machine context (of course you could have one instance per machine)

* The upshot of 1/3 is that it simplifies the messages passed around in the planning stack, though you're pushing the coupling away to the map abstraction

* If we pursue a 1/3 style approach (where each relevant node has direct access to the map DB), then I would suggest something like [Uint64MultiArray](http://docs.ros.org/jade/api/std_msgs/html/msg/UInt64MultiArray.html) for a first pass. The main reason is that the assumption that each map entity should be uniquely identifiable by 64 bits seems fairly reasonable, and plus this is a built-in type which makes life a little bit easier as a first pass

* If we shoot for something like 2, then I have no idea. I think for that we would have to come up with a couple variations of map-based prediction, localization, and behavior planning to get a sense for what would be needed there
* Do you have any concrete, high level behaviors you're envisioning here? Or even in the case of recovery behavior for each component of the planning stack? I ask this because I think it's impossible to design a reasonable interface without some concrete use-cases, even if we push the problem of implementation to others
* [OMPL](http://ompl.kavrakilab.org/api_overview.html) has a very reasonable API and separation of concerns for motion planning that at least bears some studying
* [MoveIt!](http://moveit.ros.org/documentation/concepts/) IMO is more ROS-y in terms of it's paradigms, and less useful for general motion planning

* Some other things we would need to be aware of and think about in designing an interface are different kinds of planners and planning paradigms, e.g.
  
  * Trajectory planning (combined lateral and longitudinal) vs path + velocity planning decomposition (e.g. what Autoware currently does)
  * Optimization-based methods vs sampling-based methods vs hybrid (n-stage) methods
  * etc...

* I personally take more of an optimization-based view of motion planning (and everything else for that matter), so from this view, just some random things to consider for an interface/problem definition:
  * objective function (e.g. progress, smoothness, weights etc..)
  * state space/motion model (e.g. dubins bicycle, first order wheels etc.., what level of derivative to control..)
  * time horizon
  * discretization level (in time or space domain)
  * initial conditions
  * state space constraints (e.g. 0 <= x <= 10)
  * obstacle constraints
  * waypoint constraints
* If I'm understanding your interface correctly, why would we need workspace to be a parameter rather than keeping the workspace as a set of class variables? Or do you mean workspace to mean something like the broad solution domain of the problem (e.g. 0 <= x <= 10)?
1. Make the code quality better

2. Make it easier for developers to develop algorithms that can interact with other developer's algorithms
1. General development guidelines (e.g. ROS code should only be boilerplate, turn on all warnings, not doing XYZ will get your MR rejected, etc. most open source projects have developer guidelines IIRC)
2. High level description of architecture (e.g. simple block diagrams) + high level descriptions of what each component does (high level UML here?)

3. More detailed descriptions of the architecture and components (class-level UML here?):
   
   * the more concrete expected behavior of each component
   * the API's for commonly defined libraries (i.e. motion planning)
   * the interface (i.e. message definitions)
   * some sample use cases and expected behavior in each case
# Example file structure
AutowareAuto/
| src/
| | planning/
| | | README.md # <-- here
| | perception/
| | # ...

Behaviour planning => open problem, Darpa urban challenge: rule-based, other companies: search-based method, our favorite: robust POMDP
Local planning => some deterministic sampling-based methods (GMT) or form of MPC, pre-recorded path, RRT
Control

map
