issue_title: Optimizing self-collision checks?
issue_contents: After changing the FCL cache for world and attached objects (

) now self collision checking shows up as a remaining big consumer of time. I know that the combination of joint limits and Allowed Collision Matrix (ACM) allows to shortcut some collision checks here. However I still wonder if we could do more? Something like a "conditional" ACM maybe? (example: if j1 < 90°, don't check "left side-pane" at all)
Any ideas? Other approaches? (I ask mainly out of curiosity as I think I now need to optimize different parts of the system ... )

I think it would help but when monitoring the solving of the motion plan, moveit reconstruct the collision environment every time a collision check is requested. This is a large percentage when performing thousands of checks also not directly related to moveit current there is not a way to indicate if a collision object is a convex hull so everything is represented as a detailed mesh. Changing these two factors provides a 5-10x improvement.

I am currently working making the collision package with tesseract_collision self contained. Once finished I will start discussion with the moveit maintainers on how they would like to approach integrating the new capability as it will require some major changes to the api to get the performance benefits.

issue_title: Automatic Parameter Tuning
issue_contents: Create a tool to automatically tune navigation2 node parameters using state of the art machine learning techniques.

Currently, the default parameters in the system are some combination of magical numbers, specific to one robot platform (i.e. turtlebot), or may have previous insight. Frankly, there are likely too many parameters in the stack for non-advanced users to tune manually or understand the impact on navigation performance. Dynamic parameter tuning will be achieved soon via dynamic callbacks in the stack (a feature coming soon and already in our milestones), but a tool to automatically tune a subset of parameters would be a potential asset to the stack and various robot platforms/applications. The tool could select a subset of existing navigation2 parameters and through Bayesian optimization techniques create test cases to vary parameters and optimize results.
This seems like a large undertaking (even PID tuning is still alot of human in the loop!). I'd first ask for a list of
magic numbers we think this might be good to solve.
I think most things are either geometric or pretty clear what its needed for (max speed, timeouts, samples). The weights of DWB I think is an interesting candidate, implementation details aside.
This seems like a large undertaking (even PID tuning is still alot of human in the loop!). I'd first ask for a list of
magic numbers we think this might be good to solve.

I don't deny this would be a significant task, though I am in the process of scoping this feature now. I would say that almost any parameter that is not a property/state of the robot, sensor, or environment itself could be a candidate parameter to be tuned, though in practice for this tool I would have the user select a subset of interest. As you mentioned, the controller server parameters are candidates, some in AMCL and costmap layers too. I think this would be generalize-able to parameter tuning even outside this stack depending on how it is implemented.
Also, there have been strong demonstrations in literature of automatic tuning of controllers with humans out of the loop! See this
Sure... usually I’ve seen auto tuning and then a human still tops it off.
Can you be specific on what parameters in AMCL or costmap layers? Most (if not all?) of these values also have physical property meanings so I’m not sure what weights you’d be autotuning.
I think something that could optimize the local costmap resolution and area as a function of robot speed limits, and something that could optimize
based on map grid critic resolution, robot critics, and speed limitations would help me, a non-advanced user.
The resolution isn't generally related to speed, its related to how close you need to get to objects, how accurate your positioning is, and how much CPU you want to dump into it.
Similar with the samples -- those are mostly "as many as you can handle in your design spec" on CPU load and how fast you want to run your controller
maybe I need to read the documentation, not an auto param tuner :O
When we started missing our controller timing, we tuned the
params and controller rate based on how velocities*sim_time would be binned in the map_grid critics.

I can definitely see DWB critic weights and some AMCL weights being tunable, though extremely challenging and data intensive. You can’t really tune amcl in simulation, perhaps DWB you might but defining the spec would be interesting.

The costmap “stuff” i think is nearly all geometric and you shouldn’t need to tune anything in particular. The local costmap size I suppose could be tunable relative to some CPU load target, but my intuition says that folks’ applications will be the best decider for that (something around moving things will want a larger costmap than others, if youre simulating 10s ahead, you need 10s
2 of costmap size at minimum around, etc).

Again, not saying it doesn’t have its place, but I think a proposal like this needs specific things we can point to to say “tune this” and decide that “yes these are parameters appropriate to be autotuned”.
I would consider costmap parameters such as

are some candidates as well. We've already mentioned the DWB critic weights, and if we expect the affect on CPU load for some parameters to affect some performance criteria, then they would be candidate parameters as well.

My thought behind this was to consider the tool as a "mostly" black box optimization and it is up to the user to decide which parameters are of interest to autotune via testing for their context/criteria. I have experience with Bayesian Optimization techniques, so I'm not completely out of my element in proposing this idea.

So the alpha_x parameters are motion model and are characteristic of a robot. I expect most professional users do some robot modelling and pick derived numbers. With that said, autotuning could be a way to achieve similar results but those numbers are actually meaningful.
Min/max particles I could see being tunable as well. In my experience these really are big problems for response time and smoothing tradeoffs.
Inflation radius is meaningful geometrically to the robot base. Scaling cost could be tunable. Resolution I dont think is necessary to tune.

I think the issue you'll run into in this line of thinking is: how do I generate either ground truth or create metrics to optimize against. For AMCL, you cannot meaningfully tune in simulation since its heavily dependent on real robot characteristics (how off-model is the drive system, wheel slippages, real environment dynamic changes, etc). For DWB, coming up with a metrics to optimize for is an undertaking but conceptually I dont think there's anything blocking you from doing that in simulation.

Food for thought. In my experience the 2 most challenging and time consuming things to tune are a controller, when you implement a controller the way DWB is, and AMCL. I'd stick with those if going down this line of thinking since the costmap parameters (less cost scale factor) are all geometric.

My opinion is that this ticket should be closed unless  there's someone specific that's interested and actually going to commit to implementing this in the 12 month time horizon. Otherwise its kind of a wishlist item that's going to sit around

I don't think an argument per parameter is really the point of this ticket, as we've already illuminated several parameters which could be "tunable". I am also the person who has an interest in implementing (or at minimum scoping out the needed work for a formal design proposal) this feature, especially as I see value in said tool not simply in the navigation2 stack but for ros2 in general. I wouldn't close this ticket as it should be part of the discussion on future features for the stack. I posted this issue at request of
for this exact purpose, but I appreciate your thoughts.
issue_quotes: This seems like a large undertaking (even PID tuning is still alot of human in the loop!). I'd first ask for a list of
magic numbers we think this might be good to solve.
contents_details_more: Use of 3rd party machine learning library?
ROS2 wrapper for defining test case, optimization criteria, and retrieving results

issue_title: The States in the Concurrency Container does not Run Parallally as Intended.
issue_contents: I have created a flexbe behavior to test the working of concurrency container. The concurrency container contains 3 states which should run parallelly. Each of these 3 states basically publishes a unique string to 3 different topics. The value published by the topic is printed using "rostopic echo" ROS command. But when I run the behavior, the 3 concurrency states do not print  the strings simultaneously instead prints the strings one after another. This is not how the parallel states should run in a concurrency container. Instead, all the 3 strings should be printed at once. I have attached my flexbe behavior graph and code.
The below two images show the behavior flow.
I have attached the behavior and the code for the individual states below.
Am I doing anything wrong here?
Not sure what exactly you mean by "printed at once" and "one after the other".

One aspect I would like to point out is the difference between parallel and concurrent. In the concurrency container, all children are active at the same time, but they are not parallelized in the sense of multithreading or multiprocessing. Instead, they are indeed processed in sequence and each state is executed at its own rate, but they are the "active" state at the same time.
Underlying assumption here is that none of the execute methods is actually a blocking or time-consuming operation, as in general for FlexBE.
Does this cover your observation or do you think there is something wrong in the way the concurrency is working in practice? Note that there is the recent issue reported in
that might have an effect on your example as well.

issue_title: map_server: reload_map_from_file service?
issue_contents: I was wondering if it would be useful to implement a service on map_server to reload the map from a file. I think it would be beneficial in multi-floor environments where one needs to change the map due to the robot changing floors, instead of having to kill the  map_server node and starting it again with the map of the new floor.
Please let me know if this can be already achieved by some other means
One way I have seen folks do multi-floor is to lay all the floor maps next to each other on a single map and then "teleport" the robot between floors when it goes into an elevator.
That said, loading a new map seems a bit better. The only concern than would be that everything that consumes the map updates correctly.
The "teleporting" option might be a quick hack, but I don't think that should be considered "best practice".
In my humble opinion, that the map consumers updates correctly should be a concern... for the map consumers, don't you think?
Anyway, I am going to implement this feature for my own project so, I will send a pull request :)

This is another use case where layered costmaps are useful. Rather than teleporting the robot, I've created several static maps that share the same coordinate system. Then, when a new map is published on the /map topic, the static data will be swapped out for the new data.

What I'd recommend doing is creating a map_mux that takes several published topics (/floor1_map /floor2_map etc) and switches which one of them is published to /map can be changed by the method of your choosing.

Thanks for your suggestion David. I think it is a good idea, but what would be the advantage of having all the maps loaded in memory at the same time (which can be a non negligible amount of memory) in contrast with loading them from disk when needed?

I'd say its the ROS-iest way to do it, with the added benefit of having no changes to map_server. You could also have multiple robots on different floors, perhaps. I have no response about the amount of memory.
From a ROS-iness point of view, sounds reasonable. I think I'll do it this way although we might want to give it some more thought.
node will receive a list of
services + a default map topic (using rosparam perhaps?)
service according to the selected source
that will effectively switch the map topics to be published and static_map service to be referenced.
And a parameter configuration example could be:
My one suggestion would be: if making a mux, maybe don't make it specifically for maps. There already exists a

node which is frequently used with cmd_vel (the Pr2 for instance uses this mux to switch between joystick and application commands, allowing the joystick to override the application so you can steer away from danger). Of course, mux doesn't work for multiple topics (like your map/map_metadata stated above), but this is a common thing (cameras for instance typically have a camera_info topic in addition to the actual camera data). I can imagine that a multi_topic_mux (n*m->n topics, where current is m->1) would be quite useful in general.

Bah, right after hitting enter I noticed the static_map aspects. I guess that would be slightly different from a generic node. However, I would note that your mux already has the map (since it has to pass the map through itself), and so it should be able to just advertise the static_map service itself and return the last map passed through the mux (no need to even tell the mux about the other static map services, they won't be used by anybody).
you are right, there is no need to tell the mux about the other static_map services. Regarding a generic node... might be out of my time availability :p

Hello everybody, I am using map_server to load my maps to navigate my robot.  But the maps are  not already exist. They are  produced in real time. I don't want to respawn my map_server node frequently. So I want to know if there is a way to load my map dynamically with map_server .Could you tell me how to do in a appropriate way? Thank you .
you tell me how to solve my problem I raised above. Thank you all
If the map is being created in realtime -- why is map_server even involved? I would expect that the mapping program (be it gmapping, karto, cartographer, etc) would be publishing the map directly.

,I want to use my UAV  to capture the image data in the air, and the image can be changed to a map after some treatment like using deep learning.  After that I want to use the map  to navigate my robot.The only tool I can use is map_server  because I am using move_base.So  I want to know if I can use map_server to load my map dynamically. I don't need  to use the map comes from gmapping. Do you have any idea?

，I did think about it before ，but I don't know the process  to publish a /map  by myself ，is there any tutorial about this ？Or maybe I can only see how to do it from inside the code in map_server. could you tell me? Thanks
I have found a tool to change sensor_msgs/Image to nav_msgs/OccupancyGrid . I wiil try it.

issue_title: Move locks from move_base into individual planners
issue_contents: It seems kind of to be done in the case the local planner wants to do something with the local costmap in the computeVelocityCommands function. This seems to be overkill and maybe restricting the performance.
In our case the computeVelocityCmmands sometimes takes a while, but we don't keep the updating of the local costmap locked during that time.

. I think it makes sense to lock the costmaps when about to read them in the planners, so you don't read them right when they are cleaned (I have seen this happens often), but that should be the responsibility of the planners themselves, done in the right moment to minimize the blocking time.
To a large extent, the default planners all assume a consistent world state throughout a planning cycle. I concur that it probably

be in the planner itself, but that is made slightly difficult because while we can update all the default planners, we don't have the ability to update all the planners out there that may be relying on our costmap locking in move_base.

I would suggest that if we want to change this, we only do it in lunar and above if we do it very soon, or we do it in a later release if we cannot fix it ASAP. That limits the impact of the change on operational systems.
Adding help wanted to note that maintainers do not currently plan to tackle this, but PRs are welcome!
, we plan to drop this locking and advice plugin developers to adapt their code.

As a showcase of why we think this is a good thing, the sbpl_lattice_planner can take an arbitrary time to compute a plan (configurable), while it just need some tens of milliseconds to make his own copy of the global costmap.
I've changed the title of this ticket to the actionable fix we want to implement
Can I ask for some clarification on the motivation here, please?

Firstly, it's the move_base node which combines perception and planning. Therefore, it is the place that knows whether there is a possibility for conflict on shared resources, and thus it should do the locking. It's a fairly easy mod to make the locking go away completely, for example.
Secondly, I don't see the point.
wrote this "may be impacting performance". What is meant by that? Given that the planner is the only consumer of the costmap, locking caused by the planner itself impacts nobody else.

planner can take very long and that it's cheaper to copy the costmap. Firstly, that depends on the size of global costmap -- when it's large, copying is significant cost. We regularly run move_base in environments of 500mx500m at 10cm resolution. That's about 23MB of data

. Moreover, I again wonder what the problem is -- nobody but the global planner uses the costmap, so why worry that it's not being updated? Are you concerned with the CPU-spike due to batching the updates?
Yeah that are some valid points if you run all standard ros navi stack.
Once you go away from that and e.g want to use the costmaps also from other modules then, nope.
As far as I know most companies use a modified version of the navi stack, maybe switching out planners, using a different costmap layers and so on.
Even if you just switch out planners, having the costmap locks in the move_base above the planners makes it impossible to do any smarter locking.

Anyways for me this is actually not an issue anymore as we gradually moved away from the standard costmaps. Also I think I will try to avoid working much with the navi stack in the future ... it really is just good for early prototypes.

That copy time issue can be avoided with some kind of double / multi buffered costmap using differential updates. Basically you keep a costmap copy and just update it differentially while the originally costmap runs at a higher update rate.

Can you say a bit more about which performance issues you're seeing, concretely? It would help us understand what the requirements of those "other modules" are, that require a different locking strategy.
From my side, I would say, locking in a fine-grained manner is

better in general. It is a guiding principle to hold a lock as short as possible, but this is just one of several consideration to take into account. To give just one example, every lock operation is a problem for real-time processing -- you can get preempted on mutex calls.

Regarding that most companies use a modified version of the navstack: That is also what I observe. In fact, several of them (including my own) have completely independent implementations of a navigation architecture.

That said, the standard move_base could still have considerable value for interactions between companies and academia, as well as providing a baseline, so it's not pointless to improve it. Some people have suggested replacements for the overall move_base node, but this issue goes beyond, by also considering the assignment of responsibilities between modules.
Other process is also using the costmap, global or local planner is taking long and thus slows down this unrelated process down.
If the locking is planner specific it is up to the planner to lock it the whole time or only every time it is accessing it.
Architecture wise it would make sense to have locking and non-locking access (depending on the interface you use) and getCopy functions for the costmap to make everybody happy.
But again that's stuff for a re-write.

From my own benchmarking on DWA-derived local planners, the part that takes the longest overall is the scoring -- and this needs read access to the costmap. Also, scoring needs to compare different trajectories, so it mustn't change inbetween. Fine-grained locking has no benefit here.

For local planners where the trajectory generation step takes longer (e.g., due to use of a more complex robot model), we might see more of a benefit. I don't have any of those available for benchmarking right now, but if that's what you guys do, you could profile it and let us know.

That said instead of moving locking into the planner, it would also be possible to extend the local planner interface to have stages, where one stage needs costmap access and others maybe don't. This would enable much more parallelism, also for the planner stage, not just for other processes.

An advantage of this would be that it could be done backwards-compatible for everything derived from base_local_planner, because we can add empty methods for these stages (as opposed to moving locks, which would require modification of all the planner implementations).
Another approach could be to use reader-writer locks, but this wouldn't enable as much parallelism, due to the serialization constraint between costmap updates and planning.
I also don't have anything for benchmarking available anymore. It is a no-issue now for us but I think still would be an good improvement (although I am strongly for a full re-write of this thing).
Yeah the stages approach would work for the sake of backwards compatibility.
will you be at ROSCon? If yes, how about a chat?
Nope, I sadly won't be at ROSCon.
Also might tune out of this issue as I will quit the company soonish and have no idea what I will work on next :>
,  I'll be at ROSCON;  hope we will have plenty of time to talk about navigation!

For the example about the global planner I mentioned above, believe me, we have VERY big environments to deal with. And making the local, planner-specific copy of the costmap takes negligible time compare to the planning itself.
FYI, and sorry for the off-topic: talking about alternative navigation frameworks, we are presenting our own at ROSCON:

I guess it depends on your planning architecture. We typically first use topological planning for planning in the large, and then a costly planner (not from SBPL exactly, but close enough) only for relatively short paths, between the nodes of the topological graph. In this situation, planning doesn't take so long, and the overhead of copying the map would be considerable, I surmise.

btw, I'm aware of MBL, and I like the approach of taking the state-machine out of move_base, and switching to an action-based interface instead. I would go even further and split up local and global planning into separate nodes -- putting them into one made sense as long as local and global planning were tightly coupled, but since you've removed that coupling anyway, I don't think its necessary anymore. But we can talk about that length at ROSCon ;-)

issue_title: Grab testing data and store it for future testing
issue_contents: Consider creating a folder with input data from sensors: camera, gps, etc. for testing purposes. Preferably this will be in rosbag formats for easy consumption - host this in a share somewhere and not the repo to avoid people downloading 1GB of bagfiles needlessly.
On another note, ROSbags do get pretty big (1GB/10 seconds of zed data).
Could consider buying an external 1TB to store it in and people pull in data as they need.
I'm a bit against storing things on a physical external drive, as it's much more likely to get lost or disorganized. Perhaps we could reach out to Google for some sponsorship help there?
That's also a good point. Let's discuss this at meeting tomorrow.

- we should revisit this issue with the upcoming test cart that the mechanical team is building. I think if we're not capturing zed. For reference, ~30 seconds of rosbag capturing almost all the sensor data from the robot (sans the camera/pointcloud data) is about 3mb.

Hi, I would mainly like to confirm on how the voltage is being read. Is it because due to the fact that OpenCR could be treated like an arduino, there is a specific function in the code that is reading the voltage or is there an internal voltage sensor?

In addition, is it possible to change the provided code so that current can be read and recorded by the turtlebot or the remote PC? Or would a seperate current sensor be required in order to read the current?
This is mainly because i need information on power used by the turtlebot.
Hi, the battery voltage is read from OpenCR and delivered to RPi via rosserial. You can read the topic
Publishing the battery status code is written in
Unfortunately, OpenCR does not have current sensing feature, but by evaluating the voltage level, you can assume the power consumption during certain period of time.
Then is it possible to add a separate current sensor to the OpenCR to let it read current?
Yes, you can add additional sensors on OpenCR as there are multiple GPIO and ADC as well as serial ports available.

issue_title: CVT for JAUS IOP testing
issue_contents: How do I get a CONFORMANCE VERIFICATION TOOL (CVT) to test whether I am able to implement the standards or not. I cant find this in internet. Its private I guess, only for NAMC members.
Is there any other way of testing whether I have done stuff correctly?
You're right, CVT is only for members.
The stuff of iop/ros bridge should be complient. So you can test your stuff against the bridge or use only the components of the bridge ;)
Are the client services something similar to CVT?
Yes, client services are similar to CVT, but without tests of all functionality. The client services uses only relevant parts for bridge.
So when we will have a CVT will the OCU client be running?
Then how is ocu client a CVT?

a CVT is a tool to test your JAUS/IOP components on the robot. It sends messages (wrong and correct) defined by test profiles and analyze the responses from robot. If they are not as expected CVT reports an error. CVT tries to cover all defined messages of a service/all services.

An OCU client is a component with a set of configured JAUS/IOP services which control the robot and consumes sensor information from this robot. The sensor information is translated to ROS messages, which can be visualized by e.g. rviz or rqt.
OCU client uses not all messages defined by a standard. The supported features are described by a README of each client, e.g.
Can we please know the difference between a normal service and a client service e.g. Discovery and Discovery Client. It is not very evident in the documentation.
Discovery is a service, usually running on robot. DiscoveryClient support the access to Discovery from OCU side.
Perhaps it is easier to understand on
The GPS position flow is as follow:
ROS NavSatFix -> GlobalPoseSensor (ROBOT) ---- radio --- (OCU) GlobalPoseSensorClient -> ROS NavSatFix
ROBOT or OCU side can be replaced by other IOP compliant software.
Does this mean that OCU client is a part of the CVT and not our robot?
OCU is an Operator Control Unit and means your control software running NOT on your robot.
CVT is a test tool which sends and receives the same massages like OCU, but does not visualize the sensor data and does not send meaningful control commands.

How do I use OCU client to create any Event to which my platform manager should respond or a client to query for liveness and make my platform manager respond or any other service apart from Discovery which is described in the documentation?
Do we have to generate "*_sm.cpp" files for all services as mentioned in jaustoolset guide or is there some other way?

I tried to make a Liveness Client using JTS as mentioned in the guide but my liveness service does not respond to it (though the Liveness server created using the guide responds). Is there any way to check what is the message sent in sendJausMessage?
Sorry, I don't understand what you try to do.
Do you will use IOP compliant services on robot? Setup an IOP comliant robot? Create your own IOP services?
This ROS/IOP Bridge make your ROS services availabe for IOP compliant OCU's. You need only configure your ROS launch files. See
If you want control an IOP compliant robot, you need to setup client service of the ROS/IOP Bridge. See
To control the robot from OCU, you need to get access control. For this purpose you need the "AccessControl" rqt plugin from iop_rqt_accesscontrol_fkie.
If you still want create your own plugin

What I intend to do is that I already have a ROS robot ready. Now I want a JAUS layer over my robot which can respond to CVT e.g. if CVT queries for liveness,  then my robot should respond to it. I dont think I will have to implement my own services because most of the services which I require are already present in the package. I am just unable to figure out a way to test them.
Creating the launch file as described in

I think the services are already created. When I echo /iop_system I get the list of services which means that the Discovery service works.  But what about the other services e.g events,  liveness etc. How do I make OCU test other services so that my robot responds to the queries in appropriate manner
If you have setup the bridge for the robot and has already discovered it, most of work is done.
Setup a component with client services for services you uses on your robot:
1.1. e.g. if you configured on you robot PrimitiveDriver, you need need PrimitiveDriverClient on your OCU component
. This plugin display all discovered robots using '/iop_system' topic by default.
Setup wireshark to see which JAUS messages are exchanged between your components.
2.2. change JTS configuration file to receive all JAUS messages on loopback. This file should be included in your config, e.g
In rqt-AccessControl click on discovered robot name to trigger the event creation to get JAUS/IOP reports from robot.
3.1.1 AccessControl-plugin sends a command to the OCU component through
events for different reports are created. You can also change in your OCU component to request the reports
3.2 How can I see what happens:
3.2.1 Success or errors are displayed in
of the ROS node (OCU component) (increase log level for different plugins).
3.2.4 ROS topic output of the ROS node (OCU component).

There is no guarantee you pass all of CVT tests! CVT sends a command and expect what the report contains the predifined values. If this values are different, you can change most of these by parameter, e.g.
Currently there is no client for liveness service, so no request are generated for it, but the service itself pass the CVT test.

I am able to connect to my robot from the rqt access control and when I give it a "ocu/cmd_vel" my robot moves (in simulation). Does it mean that the jaus ros bridge is properly setup and it is something like CVT controlling the robot? Or is it only ros messages because superficially, there isnt anything like JAUS which I can see. When I echo /is_controlled it shows "true".
And /iop_system list all my services even before I access control my robot from rqt. Is that suppose to happen?

I could set up wireshark and I know its configured for JAUS messages because when I play an example .pcap file, I can read decoded JAUS messages. But when I launch my launch files, I dont get any JAUS messages. All of them show TCP Protocol. How do I get the Jaus messages? I have edited nm.cfg file to change "EnableLoopback" to 1 as mentioned in guide.
Also I noticed that when I launch jaus_node_manager it shows "Unable to bind to UDP port 3794" and "Unable to bind to UDP Loopback port 55555". Can this be a possible reason. What do I do about it?

Another thing which I noticed is that of I edit nm.cfg file and type anything gibberish,  jaus node manager launches without any error other than the UDP port one.  I am certain that I am editing the correct nm.cfg file which is loaded with JTSNodeManager. How is it possible?
My jaus node manager launch file

And after I get wireshark working I can see the jaus messages, but my robot will not respond on its own, right? The client will have to query something like "set emergency" or anything else. rqt access is only for cmd_vel. How do I control the other things.
The "Unable to bind to UDP port 3794" error occurs if the JTS node manager was launched twice without to stop the first one. Somethime it does not stop for some reason... Search for process
The easiest way to see that the right file was loaded is to change the
_. If you install your build code it is perhaps a different location of the nm.cfg.

To control other things you need on the robot the right service, .e.g.
and a ROS tool to generate the waypoint. It can be rviz, your ROS package or something else.
I get the jaus messages now but only for query identification in wireshark. Even though my robot is moving by /ocu/cmd_vel in rqt, there are no jaus messages in wireshark
I did not tested the dissector file. Do you see other UDP messages which are not marked as JAUS?
Yes. And the UDP and Jaus messages have the same source and destination. Dont know if that matters

query identification message are the only message send using multicast. All other messages are send as unicast message. You can't change the presence vector of ReportLocalPose!
On robot side you have to look at each bit of the presence vector and decide which information should be reported. If first bit is set you have to report the X position. So you set it:
The value of 65535 was chosen because of type of presence vector. It is enough to set it to 255 to get all values of report local pose.

in iop_builder_fkie.  And pass instead of
. (see e.g. GlobalWaypointDriver.xml) Than run catkin build and look for changes in
It has not effect on robot side in this bridge, but other IOP compliant robots should look at the presence vector.

By setting presence vector in client you can reduce the message size transmitted over the radio link, because you are not interested in e.g. orientation or hight(Z) values. Not in this implementation, but perhaps in other IOP compliant implementation.

issue_title: [jsk_rviz_plugins/video_capture] Fix frame rate
issue_contents: Some frames seem to be dropped and thus the video plays much faster than how reality happened.
are you planning to add this feature?
It's a bug report. Unfortunately, I don't have time at the moment to look into it.
In current implementation, a captured image is written to output video at every rendering loop on rviz.
So unless rviz rendering fps luckily matches video fps you set, you will see fast/slow play on recorded video, though output video fps is accurately set by this plugin.
A possible solution is to create ros::WallTimer and write images to video in the callback.
It may improve the frame rate a little bit, but accurate frame rate is difficult to be achieved because it's not real-time.
How about using an external screencast tool like kazam?
Thanks for your insights on the current implementation.

In the end, I used a screencast tool with a lot of manual work. I had a folder of about 200 rosbags which I wanted to compare. They need the exact same resolution, perspective and frame rate. Doing this manually was quite time-consuming.
Since I use rosbags, I don't need
For normal graphs, I implemented my own
like tool, which advanced time in the rosbag for the amount of time one frame needs. If it's possible to manually feed
with ROS messages and then call some screenshot function, this would perfectly solve my problem.

issue_title: tf2 integration
issue_contents: Brain mentioned about the new model for tf message which helps to reduce the tf transform computation.
tf2 is a server/client model for tf messages. tf2 may help the tf transform computation in low-power system like android.
It's quite stable now.  There's one namespace issue left from a past
review, but the math is solid.  We're using it in the pr2_plugs stack.
It's designed to support slower connections and optimize processor usage
etc.   It's mostly been waiting on a strong driving use case to recommend
it for replacement of tf.  And there's lots of documentation that will need
There's one outstanding issue which may be worth waiting another revision
which is how to deal with multiple homogeneous robots. We're starting to
look to tf2 again here at Willow. We setup a SIG for it at
but havent had time to work on
On Wed, Oct 3, 2012 at 7:40 PM, Daniel Stonier
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/
It came up talking with Brian and Adam about the android rviz. The tf there consumes alot of computation power on the android since it receives messages and does calculations locally.

Brian suggested running a tf2 server on the robot and have the android contact the server for results. i.e. effectively moving all that computation off the android to the robot. Seems like a very nice use case for any robot-tablet (or smart phone) interaction, be it rosjava based or web app based.
issue_quotes: I like this!!!!!!
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/
#issuecomment-9129002.

issue_title: aruco_detect performance on TX2 and implementing nodelets
issue_contents: Are there any plans to add nodelets to reduce the CPU consumption?

I've gotten up to about 30fps on a TX2 after switching to the opencv default aruco detector parameters from the defaults the ros aruco_detect package sets (I was getting about 8 fps previously) but the CPU usage is still pretty high at 30fps. I'm thinking the next step would be to make aruco_detect a nodelet.
Any thoughts on how to get aruco_detect run more efficiently?

As much as I like extracting the parameters from urdfs -- as it would mean less work for users -- it might be best to actually do the work manually and hard-code the parameters in the various plugins / configurations.
We've had users change base xacros in the past (adding tool frames and links, changing
fi) which broke the IKFast plugins in various ways (I would say:
ways, but it wasn't obvious apparently).

As OPW has quite strict requirements on the kinematics of a manipulator for the algorithm to work, supporting automated extraction would seem to increase chances that users try to use any plugin(s) on their own xacros/urdfs, which will most likely fail.
From a maintenance / support perspective, a setup similar to the IKFast plugins (ie: hard-coded to match with one specific kinematic configuration) might actually be preferable.

issue_title: Check if a generated trajectory is smooth
issue_contents: There are cases where the generated trajectories contain jagged regions. It would be extremely hard and time consuming to go back and check which TrajectoryRequest caused that trajectory. But it might be feasible to do a check after a trajectory is generated to make sure it is continuous everywhere. If it is not, we can print out some warning message to make it easier to identify the cases where this happens.

issue_title: Publish diagnostics_agg right away upon new warn/error diagnostics
issue_contents: The present behaviour is to only publish the aggregated diagnostics at the fixed rate (default 1Hz):

I believe that it would be better to trigger an immediate publish of the aggregated topic when a diagnostic transitions to WARN or ERROR. We have some error reporting mechanisms that currently have to subscribe to
if we knew that a) no error reports would be missed, and b) new error reports would be passed through immediately.
This sounds like a good idea, but is there any particular advantage to working with
? I guess the main thing would be fewer callbacks, and the filtering that you define through the analyzers would be applied so you only see the diagnostics you're interested in.
At the same time, it seems to me that the main purpose of the
right now is to provide information to a GUI, which is why the update rate is slow.
I guess what I'm wondering about is whether the purpose of the aggregator is to provide an aggregation of the most up to date diagnostics at any point in time, or just in slices.
is the GUI, but I think its
is to supply a single diagnostic snapshot which doesn't require opening a socket to every node which produces diagnostics.
Even for the GUI case though, IMO a new ERROR case should be made visible as soon as possible, rather than waiting as much as a second for the next report to arrive.
Definitely agree with making errors visible ASAP.
What about changing messages that are attached to the diagnostics? Does it matter that the cause of the error is different, but the level is still the same?
Should both of these messages cause an instant update, or just the first one? Does that also apply to when the level is
From my perspective, I don't think it makes sense to update instantly on changed messages in the
levels, but it might if the diagnostic is in the

level. It's a pretty small change to make though, in terms of implementation - just a check on an additional field of the message. Doing this might cause updates to be too frequent, for example if your message contains some floating point values which change a lot.
From personal experience, I'd suggest a few adjustments to this:
issue_code:
level: 2
name: ''
message: something went wrong...
hardware_id: ''
values: 
  - 
    key: ''
    value: ''
---
level: 2
name: ''
message: something else went wrong...
hardware_id: ''
values: 
  - 
    key: ''
    value: ''
---
contents_details_more: on change doesn't reduce the latency if the diagnostic_updater library is limiting changes on
to 1Hz, so to implement this properly, both would need to updated to publish updates immediately when items go from OK to not OK
Industrial users will want to know the end-to-end latency between a node transitioning to an error state and the diagnostics_agg topic reflecting that

Most industrial systems that have a periodic update (1Hz) and immediate update on change also limit the max publishing rate on change, so that a status item that is oscillating doesn't overwhelm the system. I think this is good idea here as well
I think different users will want different notification behaviors on WARN vs ERROR; it might make sense to parameterize this in the final implementation

issue_title: Not all topics synched
issue_contents: I am currently working on a Kubernetes cluster using ROS melodic (for specific project reasons melodic needs to be used). As the ros master is a single point of failure, I want to make it redundant and came across your software. Thanks for sharing it!
In the cluster every node can directly address every node via its IP.
Each ros master is running in a Kubernetes pod, this means each container inside the pod shares storage and network. In total there are three containers for each pod running the following commands:
The container image is created as following:
Note: Broadcast and multicast get enabled before start.
The master discovery seems to work correctly:
Also I do not see any errors in the sync output:
For test purpose there is realsense (camera) node which is publishing data from the camera. This will create a certain amount of topics and the realsense randomly registers add one of the masters.
At master one, I see the following topics:
At master 2 there is only a small subset of the topics available:
It looks like there seems to be some synchronization but it seems to not work completely.
Do you see any problems in the set up? Is there some output/log files I should consult?
is there a reason why you use
It could be a problem if ROS_MASTER_URI and ROS_IP has not the same entry, since they are not resolved by master sync.
For more output you can run master_sync with
(run twice, if you do no see debug output)

is done, because the hostname is per default not resolvable in kuberenetes. I did so to achieve that the IP address is used instead of the hostname. Which seems to work if I check the discover output:

For the realsense this is not done . Instead its ROS_HOSTNAME is set to the name (in this case "realsense") of a "headless kubernetes service" which is pointing to the pod and the container contained.

With just one master this is done also for the ros master. But with multiple masters the service "ros-master" should resolve to all instances and connection will be randomly distributed between the masters. Following this, it should be transparent for a client if a master goes down or comes up, if all masters are synched.
Therefor, I used the trick of setting the ROS_IP in order to not use the ROS_HOSTNAME.
Just as a side note: With just one standard ros master everything is working as expected.
I tested with setting the ROS_MASTER_URI to
. Unfortunately this did not solve the problem.
I will try with investigating the logs in more details this evening with the additional log level!
At which frequency are the masters synchronized?
for all ROS-Nodes (roscore, master_discovery, master_sync and realsense)?
By default the changes of local roscore are checked at 1 Hz. If changes are detected the synchronization process will be initialized. You can change the check rate in
Is it a lot of work for you to switch to github (master) version of multimaster? (You need to install grpcio and grpcio-tools with
. And multimaster packages are renamed from
It could be easier to debug ;-)
So I switched to the master branch by basically changing the docker image to the following:
This works fine and the software is running. Unfortunately the issue is not solved.
In the debug log output I see that the sync thread is receiving the correct set of remote topics:
Following this, I think the issue might be that the remote state is actually not applied but no error is raised.
Do you have any idea what could be the reason or what I could investigate?
ROS_MASTER_URI is for all nodes (except master)

There is a kubernetes service running which allows the nodes to connect to the master(s) behind that host name. And each host is using export ROS_IP=$(hostname -i), to set their ROS ip address in order to communicate with other nodes.
Thank you for switching the multimaster version!
Can you post the whole debug output?
I do not see any subscriptions. So the node or topics are filtered for some reason. It would be interesting to see the complete remote state.
Simplified example with just one topic /test:
I think, the problem is the different ROS_MASTER_URI ('
'). Since the check is only done by comparing the host names of these two URLs, the nodes are not synchronized.
I have added a fix that also resolves the hostname and IP addresses. I published it to new branch
Can you please test this fix before I put it into the master branch?
Hey thanks for providing the update.
Unfortunately, I still do not see any change.
I added the relevant output lines below.
As you mentioned before there should be some more output if a topic gets registered, e.g.:
I will try to add some more debugging output to understand better why it is not working. Maybe some check is failing due to a specific setup I have.
Thanks a lot for your support!
The problem is in this entry:
! Remote nodes (relative to roscore) are not synchronized by master_sync. It could lead to problems...
If it is not the same host and you want synchronize remote nodes anyway, you have to set
I think the remote nodes is the issue in my case. Because both roscores are running on different pods (containers) with a separate network interface.
does not work. I added a debug output but the expression
Unfortunately, I am far from being a ROS expert, I could not find the reason why the command option is not taken into account.
I disabled the check manually and now the topics get synched. The only thing I get is a warning in the discovery output "[WARN] [1580825992.122942]: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '_md5sum'".
You mentioned that there might be problems if remote hosts are synched:
What could be the problems if remote synch is used (what is unfortunately what I am looking for)?
Thanks a lot for your support!
But you have changed the code and remote nodes are synchronized anyway ;-)
checks the md5sum of remote topic with local one. I guess
can't resolve the topic class, since the node is not installed and not running in the same host/container as
(2.) is one of the problems with synchronization of remote nodes. Depending on ros-networks (multiple
nodes) and timings the remote nodes could be stopped by roscore (multiple registration of nodes with same name.) It could also lead to visualization issues in
do to dleays while tests for running state of the node.
You should start roscore, master_discovery and master_sync on each pod/container. This is the scenario what the multimaster was designed for.
I did not understand that the ROS nodes were started in another container than master_dsicovery. So the fix I did is for this problem not relevant.
Is there a reasen why you start the ROS-Nodes in different container as roscore and master_discovery?
Thanks. With setting it as local variable it works!
After all the setup is the following:

Inside the K8S cluster there is one pod for each ros program (node). Each of them is connecting to the ROS master(s). Because the ROS master is per default not backed up nor redundant, I was looking for running a redundant ROS master. Each instance of the ros master will run in their own pod. In that pod now the roscore, ros_master_sync and ros_master_discovery are running for each ros master.

But all of the other nodes never know to which master they connect, as they are connecting via a service which randomly resolves to one of the ros masters. If old of them are in synch and one crashes for what reason so ever, it should be transparent to the nodes, as they will just register or request a topic from one of the other masters, which should by in synch.

It looks that it is running now, but apparently not 100% reliable. A colleague told me that he encountered some problems, apparently some topics have not been available. I am right now trying to reproduce the issue.

issue_title: Display OBSTACLE_DISTANCE in QGC
issue_contents: What I'm looking for is a baseline implementation that we can then tune interactively with the Autonomy team and Stefan.
Suppose I have 3 sensors. One pointing straight ahead, one 15° to the right and the other 15° to the left (345°).
would have a value of 15 and I would expect 3 values in
to be used/valid. When I look at
, where is "center"? I assume this is what
Also, the array length is even, making the left/right values asymmetric.
It's in the local frame, not the vehicle frame. We should probably make that more clear in the message definition.
Ok, how do I find "straight ahead" from this?
And how would the above, 3-sensor example be represented in the array?
It's in the local frame, not the vehicle frame. We should probably make that more clear in the message definition.
and "in front of the sensor " as vehicle relative. Clearly quite a lot of docs improvements needed here.
This is how I interpret it according to what is written:

Suppose I have 3 sensors. One pointing straight ahead, one 15° to the right and the other 15° to the left (345°). increment or increment_f would have a value of 15 and I would expect 3 values in distances to be used/valid. When I look at distances, where is "center"? I assume this is what angle_offset is telling me?
I don't know if I'm "right" but my understanding, but
I guess we need to know how it has been implemented to progress.
found my description useless. Note in both cases I assume that the frame is the vehicle heading = 0 degrees. NOT North = 0degrees.
Case 1 - old style message where the points are evenly spread relative to front of vehicle. Not very flexible.

Case 2. new message. Distance array is for a chunk of data at starting at some angle relative to the 0 degree position (front of vehicle) with fixed increment spacings. May take multiple messages to cover the whole range, and this allows different messages to have different spacing of sensors.
Caveat, I guess either all messages for sensor have to be sent in a burst so they are all relative to the same heading. Probably should add something to allow better sync.
- The table sums up the possible states of the OA system. My idea is to show the user a single icon that captures both if the OA is enabled and healthy.
We also would need a switch in QGC to enable OA that basically sets  COM_OBS_AVOID to 1  and
CP_DIST to 5 to enable it and COM_OBS_AVOID to 0 and CP_DIST -1 to disabled it
I think you guys are making this more complicated than it is. In the case of a forward facing camera with a 90deg wide view (45 left, 45 right) a message would look like:
If the camera is facing directly backwards

I found a Lidar simulator that likes to deliver it's 360 data in CCW order. I'd also like to note that the left-to-right increment is not necessarily a hard requirement. That's just the positive increment direction. On ArduPilot a negative increment means left (CCW).
So, this camera data would read in the distance values, index zero first  on the right:
In the case of a forward facing camera with a 90deg wide view
What if you have 4 of those pointing in all 4 directions? Will it send 4 messages, one for each or will it consolidate all into one message?

My current implementation assumes one single message. A subsequent message would override the previous one (the previous distance slots). There is no way to identify which sensor a message is coming from.
What implementation? In the case of Ardupilot, you can receive multiple messages and they "add" internally. No need to identify them other than angle and increment
you can receive multiple messages and they "add" internally

Add to where? What GCS does this? How do you keep track of angle slots given that you have unpredictable (floating point) increment values that can be different from sensor to sensor? I guess I could keep an array and arbitrarily set its length to 360 and "fit" the distances within those slots. That would work. But I still don't know how to handle a case of a sensor going bad and stop sending data. I would not be able to detect that. Any distance set on its set of distances would get "stuck". Again, I could again add code to
these values out over time. Either way, none of this is documented.
Please take a look at the implementation.
The Ardupilot and PX4 approaches are very different here.

In PX4, if there are onboard distance sensors that are configured for collision prevention, it will use those sensors and then publishes a single fused OBSTACLE_DISTANCE message. This will be fused with the data received from an external OBSTACLE_DISTANCE message. The idea is then that that the GCS could use this to display the data that the FCU is
using to avoid, without having to attempt to replicate perfectly the internal fusion algorithm.

support multiple sources sending OBSTACLE_DISTANCE messages. They need to be fused externally before sending them in. Unfortunately it would require some fairly major architecture changes to support this.
, it seems it would be quite a pain to replicate the multi-message fusion inside of the GCS.
Would it work on AP side to publish the internal data as a new OBSTACLE_DISTANCE message for the GCS to consume? It looks like it would be fairly easy, there are already the
arrays which just need to be put into a message and published.
it looks to me like the MAVLink message definition doesn't allow for negative increments.
"If greater than 0 then this value is used instead of the uint8_t increment field."
So either we need to update that description, or shouldn't support negative increments.

ahh yes, true. The negative is only supported on the float version. Description needs to be updated. It was something I just recently added though so I doubt PX4 supports it yet. Are you willing to update the docs or would you like me/someoneElse to?
Could you update the docs? I'll get support into PX4 ASAP
issue_quotes: It's in the local frame, not the vehicle frame. We should probably make that more clear in the message definition.

Suppose I have 3 sensors. One pointing straight ahead, one 15° to the right and the other 15° to the left (345°). increment or increment_f would have a value of 15 and I would expect 3 values in distances to be used/valid. When I look at distances, where is "center"? I assume this is what angle_offset is telling me?
In the case of a forward facing camera with a 90deg wide view
you can receive multiple messages and they "add" internally
"If greater than 0 then this value is used instead of the uint8_t increment field."
contents_details_more: increment =  15, increment_f=0, distance = array with values 35, 36, 37 set with obstacle distances.  All other values set with max.
Or you might "fill in" more values at different increments - but values still centred around 35 or 35.
increment = 0, increment_f=15, angle_offset=345, just fill in first three values.
or send multiple messages, or whatever.

issue_title: Build cartographer from source (master)
issue_contents: I am able to run cartographer when everything is in the 1.0.0 version for both cartographer and for cartographer_ros.

But, I am unable to build it in master. Both cartographer and cartographer_ros give me abseil related errors. Although cartographer builds abseil itself. Is there like a guide as to how to build cartographer and cartographer_ros in master?
Is there a specific abseil version that cartographer requires? Are there any other dependencies that I miss?
, yes this resolved the problem. Thank you! is it possible to have this somewhere in the documentation?
Yes, that would indeed be very helpful. Any chance you could open a pull request for adding this to documentation?

issue_title: Calibration using evaluation - using cartographer autogenerate ground truth and compute  relations metrics for automatic calibration tool
issue_contents: I would like to create a system for automatic calibration of the lua parameters using the above tool:
The method will be as follows:
How would you recommend creating the best ground truth?
contents_details_more: First creating a ground truth pbstream by using optimization and view by eye that a good map created (optimize_every_n_nodes = 60)
Running on the same bag but change the parameters (optimize_every_n_node = 0)
Run cartographer_compute_relations_metrics between ground truth and the created pbstream
Get the minimum as possible for the sum of : (Abs translational error + Sqr translational error + Abs rotational error + Sqr rotational error).
For example today for creating ground truth I put parameters in the lua file that consume a lot of resources(high CPU) - include "optimize every_n_node"
